O891VHqqwR-TTEXcF-QypQ.text: The desserts here are awesome, o, they are more than awesome, they are like made in heaven. Love them .

HP9jy3LQQTyFT-UdFYZK3w.text: It is so tempting !!!All the cakes and pastries and scones and croissaunts heaped on the left near the entrance, so that every passer by can look and stop and look again and lick their lips and then be forced to come in.And they all look so good ... the meringues, or the cheesecakes or the tarts ... its a delight to just think of what to order.I went to Ottolenghi today, as it was the first recommendation in the french toast thread i had started ... and it had some really good french toasts. Not too heavy, but very filling ... cinnamon flavoured, with berries and syrup. My friends ordered breads and pastries, and loved the nutella and the butter and the different jams on the table. I saw some people ordering the scrambled eggs with smoked salmon, which i will have next time. Looked very appealing.It was crowded for sunday brunch, and so you might have to wait a while to be seated. But after that the service is quick and prompt. A very nice breakfast place indeed.

HwullRMiJgd3PFO8CGK40A.text: Takeaway just doesn't get better than this.Perfectly seared tuna, amazing vegetable combinations (my favourite being the aubergine with goats cheese and pine nuts), and of course the most delectable cakes and cookies. Seriously, the chocolate ganache cake is unreal. I've paid anywhere from 12 to 20 pounds for a meal with a protein, a salad or two, and dessert. It's definitely not cheap, but for the quality it's understandable.I still haven't had an actual sit-down meal here though. Ah well, it's probably best for me to leave before I can go back for seconds (and thirds and fourths) on the chocolate chip pecan cookies. And maybe just a bit more of that roasted root vegetable salad.

fUR6z5Re58TKsARjQ3eQWQ.text: In the immortal words of the wise sage L.L. Cool J., Ottolenghi is Doin' it and Doin' it and Doin' it Well. Things they do extremely, extremely well: baked goods of all shapes and sizes, crafted to perfection. Fresh, inventive salads with excellent ingredients. A cookbook that makes me drool with longing on the shiny white modern tables. Ottolenghi is a beautifully curated and displayed museum of edibles. If I lived a leeetle bit closer (and had quite a bit more in my bank account) it would be my Around The Way Girl.

gih5augvfBLPsrOWD_DYMg.text: This place is terrific. My wife and I just got his cookbook so I had to go (she'll kill me- but it was worth it). I came with high expectations and they were met. I was fortunate that the legendary line did not form until I was seated. There are only about 50 seats and most are at a communal long table. This is a plus as I got to compare raves with locals, and folks from Korea and the US (like me). The lunch menu allows you to choose from three or four salads (9 available) with the main course (6 available. The price was £13.70 or £16.20 really fair for such complex well made dishes. The wine list is excellent too with about 20 offerings by the glass and an additional 15 by the bottle- for lunch! The entree and salads are served on a single plate. Service is good and there is no pressure to turn your seat over to those waiting in line. No one appeared to wait more than fifteen minutes except a couple who wanter their own table and waited 20 minutes for it.The desserts were great and there were many flour-free offerings (which I'm sure had no calories so have two).Read "Plenty" and then go an experience it there. Cheers

0sl036eY3W9qiO14INWK5A.text: Not as amazing as I had expected. The food was good but not as exciting or the best that I have had. I had aubergine, lamb, and sea bass. All were small portions a a bit on the expensive side. Dessert looked amazing but was dry and ok.

hmndjc-CxsvqCHUgJKyADQ.text: Well I do not think this is middle eastern place. The food is very westernized. They also do not carry typical spices like sumak. So, now if you want to have to some westernized version of middle eastern food, then this place is great. This has nice ambiance, very helpful staff and some very good looking customers.It is great for big groups as well kewl for a casual date.

Tk0IbfevBQ3tio_sO9jagQ.text: Beautiful food, weekend breakfast queue didn't take too long for two, enjoyed the self-toasting and delicious jams at the communal table

afTGlWRQ_hxA1ru4NQ5XNw.text: After hearing some very positive reviews of this place we decided to try the Islington branch out for Sunday lunch. As expected the place was busy and we had to wait for 30min, but thought it'd be worth it (esp. after looking at the menu and the display of salads and mains). Indeed, food was really good, lots of vegetarian options, fresh and tasty but bit expensive and portions rather on the small side. Staff was nice and didn't rush us out, even if there were lots of people waiting for a table. Overall a lovely place to have brunch, won't be coming here if I'm startving, but will keep it on my "treats' list

Ht1w7-LaNP5v487fRP5I3A.text: i think i'll be going to every ottolenghi in london before i move back home.  i just love this place so much.  i stopped by late tonight after a yoga class, and i got a salad box to take away.  the server packed the box to the gills w/ my choices of courgette salad, a farro, pea and asparagus salad, and a salad of various green beans/peas.  everything was delicious, and i could stretch it out to 2 separate meals.  everything here is fresh and tasty, so do your body a favor and eat here.  i have yet to try their desserts, but everything looks great.

Fj1FfkhVtVH7Men_AKi2WA.text: Delicious takeaway baked goods, quite expensive deli mains, quite good hot mains.I would eat baked goods from here every day for the rest of my life without issue. Sweets in particular. They excel at them here. Swing by on a weekend morning, look at the massive line to sit down and eat, buy a couple goodies, and move along. Can't miss.If you do sit down, you'll be treated to a very nice but pricey hot menu, as well as some startlingly expensive deli items--generally nearly as much for a deli main as a hot main, despite the deli mains just sitting out--the server need only get a spoon, slop some on a plate, and serve you. They're quite good, but you're better off with take away for an excellent at-home meal.

N2vp9x2fZz47_PW-Tt7kvw.text: Very pricey so I'm knocking off a star because I'm not sure it's worth it for many of the items save one--the slightly seared tuna with ponzu sauce. I tried a few things here, but the one item that I would come back and happily dole out money for is the tuna.

eNdMrl3y2c3VthcFFCuXBA.text: I loved the food. Except the miso soup with the duck egg, which completely grossed me out. Sorry. That's probably just a personal thing. But anyways.The seating is kind of similar to Wagamama in terms of your proximity to other diners. Which isn't great considering the astronomical cost of the place (we paid £55 per head for mains, dessert and prosecco). We were there on a weekday evening, and the staff were very nice, the food is in the main delicious (although less vegetarian options than you would expect given that most of their publicity is in the vegetarian domain). Overall, I would come here occasionally but I'd definitely try to aim for a quiet period. And I really think they would do well to let people have a bit more personal space. The woman sitting next to me was on her own and clearly didn't appreciate my arrival, likewise I didn't enjoy the people on the other side of us listening in to every single word of our conversation.

IpR4dT34Zka3QSdb82Ri8g.text: Let me start by saying I didn't have a chance to eat there. The food actually looked quite good. My impression is based on service quality. I called today (Sunday) to ask about a reservation. They said no reservations, and they close at 7. They were anxious to get off the phone, and made very little effort to help me understand whether 7 means doors close at 7, seating stops at 7, the kitchen closes at 7, etc. Fair enough, it could be a busy night. So we showed up, waited to be seated. It wasn't terribly busy, but the man serving just couldn't be bothered to answer our questions (whether there was a separate dinner menu from the food on display).They just didn't seem to care that we wanted to dine there, so we found another place to eat. I'm sure the food would have been great, and I'm sure there are terrific waiters. We just had two bad service experiences in a row.

VtXRpAKKoozIH_WjOke4eA.text: Come here for the cake. Drag yourself over burning coals for the cake. It is the best in the world (I'm serious), there is no bad choice. The best spot in London for a grey day with a newspaper and pot of tea, the interior is stark but oddly comforting, and the staff second to none.

odIYOeMKUquvP2YJijwFgQ.text: Amazing food, great staff. I always go in for salad and end up eating the cake too! It's too good.

6z-wqia4h-ghNksYWoYblw.text: Beautiful food with a beautiful atmosphere, really very special. High prices but is value to the discerning who appreciate it.

fFEL-hbGCg29Oph1A2MMKQ.text: I got lots of presents for my birthday, but dinner at Ottolenghi was the best one!  We didn't make reservations, but the waitress found us a place right by the bar.  This was the most dangerous place because we were facing the outrageous desserts displayed in all their splendor.  Was really hard trying to keep our attention during the meal!  As soon as we were seated, the waitress brought us a sample of the breads - all warm and doughy.  My favorite was sprinkled with peppercorns.  We also tried a stick of the cheese bread, and I highly recommend it.  The plates here are pretty small, but don't go overboard and order too many.  For two people, I recommend getting one cold plate (we got an amazing butternut squash salad) while you are waiting for two warm plates.  I got lamb cutlets with tangy jalapeno sauce and aubergine and the other plate we got was crispy sea bass with seaweed.  Both had so many flavors in every bite!  We weren't overly full, so we decided to go for 3 desserts!  Our waitress was really helpful in telling us her favorites.  After asking her about every dessert (there were over 20!) we picked a Baileys chocolate cake (a bit dry), apple sultana cake (YUM!!!), and a rhubarb ginger cheesecake (so divine!).  Looking forward to having brunch here and for my next birthday celebration here ;-)

s6fZdsgbT5yZM40t9Q5RlQ.text: The seared tuna, the butternut squash with pine nuts, roasted aubergines, desserts to die for.... I can't even begin to pick my favs.  They don't take reservations if you go on a Sunday for brunch, so you will have to queue up.  Worth it though.   Also, the take away is very generous.SAVE room for dessert.  Sooooooo good.

YepKwhyAb5ddhdrxFyF24A.text: This location, one of four in London, is a stone's throw from the Almeida Theatre, so it's a very convenient place to eat before or after a performance. The restaurant - with an all-white decor - is small and most seating is at communal tables, so if you're anti-social or on a first date, this might not be the place for you.The menu changes daily, so it's difficult to recommend specific dishes, but the hummus, made with cannellini beans instead of the traditional chickpeas, is very smooth and has a wonderful citrus flavor, and the chicken tagine with preserved lemons, olives, and couscous will transport you to Morocco with your first bite.Portions are starter size and you'll need to order several dishes if you're hungry, so plan on spending £50 per person with wine and tip.NOTE: The restrooms are not wheelchair accessible.

XS36LGWgRCSZawuPP9M6qA.text: I know everyone loves Ottolenghi, so I went there with high hopes to treat myself to a nice lunch. The server sat me at the "bar" where I basically got blended into the queue, but on a seat. Even worse, my food was not good. The salads were pretty decent, but the salmon I was served was very cold, soggy, and nearly frozen in the middle. However, the person who rang me up generously reduced my bill a little bit after I explained that I couldn't eat my main dish. I won't be going back :(

lAZAWIqP8-bMjcx_AJYdhQ.text: Hmmm. After hearing such lovely things about Ottolenghi, I really wanted to try it out. After booking a month or so in advance, we finally secured a Saturday night seating for three. As most people probably know by now, they do a bunch of sharing plates (with a suggestion of 2-3 per person). I love to share, so that's okay. However, they also do a sharing table. As in if you book for any more than two people, you've got to sit at a communal table in the center of the room. Well, I was okay, because I was on the end, however, the other half had a really obnoxious neighbor who was sitting way too close to him, and they kept bumping elbows. The dude also kept staring ridiculously whenever anything happened. It's just an awkward situation all around. Given the size of the venue, i can see why they do it, because they can fit way more people inside, but it can just lead to awkward dining situations all around.The other half and I split a bottle of wine while Nava got a glass of white. The white was really boring. Nava described it as "If someone mixed honey and water". The red was better, but the other half wasn't that impressed. The dessert wine was alright, but not amazing. So the wine list really could use a bit of improvement.The food is actually quite tasty. Of the bread they start with, just skip everything and get lots of corn bread. That was fantastic. The rest of the bread was okay, with the focaccia bread being a bit burnt and unpleasant. We ended up with four cold dishes and four hot dishes. I thought the yellowtail was the best, followed by the beets. The eggplant was kind of boring for me, and the grilled peaches were nice, but the endive was a bit harsh for me. In the hot dishes, all four were tasty, and the truffle honey was nice on the fried zucchini blossoms, but I've had better zucchini blossoms in London. Of course we had dessert, and they were all really nice. The carrot cake was okay, I was glad it wasn't the one I ordered, as I've had much better. My berry financier was amazing though, and Nava's flourless orange and chocolate cake was fantastic. We also were lured in by the peanut butter 'Smores, but they didn't really work for me. I like peanut butter and 'Smores, but unfortunately these weren't 'Smores. So while the food is quite good, I really don't understand why the bookings fill up so quickly, because the food isn't good enough for that. (And FYI, I checked this morning and I couldn't book a 3 person table for a reasonable time on the weekend through September.) Also the communal dining really annoyed the other half due to an obnoxious neighbor. So, I'll probably not be back. However, I will probably pick up a cookbook or two. Making the recipes at home will be much easier than trying to book, and you don't have to worry about dining with people that may ruin your evening.

QV9BW3-qH-m3lBf1xiMU9w.text: Ottolenghi is one of those places that looks too fancy for me to ever visit but a colleague organised a breakfast there, and I live 6 minutes away, so who am I to refuse the invitation.Service is excellent from the moment you walk in. Attentive service and water frequently topped up without asking. Mocha (I never drink straight coffee) is so-so.This is also one of those places that has a super simple menu that makes you think  you're going to get a super tiny portion of something due to the lack of descriptive words. E.g. the welsh rarebit description is only around 8 words but translates into 2 giant pieces of bread with plenty of salad and cheese. The same with the french toast and a bean stew I had. Really big portions, excellent taste and quality and a lot less pretentious a establishment than I had envisaged.Next, I must try lunch here! Also the bread board. Wow.

S83_PLqOSsItB3ET3Z7IJg.text: Ottolenghi. A little oasis of good eating.For takeaway lunch: brave the crowds in the entrance and order a box of 3 salads. You won't regret it. Pricey yes but it's worth it. Of course you can sit down but may involve a wait or a reservation.For dinner: You will need to reserve, unless you walk in around 10pm as we did the other day and manage to snag a space. All small dishes but I like the way they just refer to them as starter size and you get to sample more of the items on the menu. Just choose a range of cold and hot dishes and share. It would be hard to only order one thing here since I usually want everything on the menu. You can't go wrong with your choice anyway.Always exciting and inventive with many combinations of ingredients and contrasting bright flavours. Late in the evening after many diners, service was great and just the right level of attention and chatty exchange.Even the bill was very moderate for the quality of food we enjoyed so this goes straight into the 5 star territory for me.Yes, I have all the cookbooks too.

h2qt9Jjmm9eazFyfsh5UEQ.text: What a way to start the morning - a delectable smoked salmon floated on a cloud of fluffy scrambled eggs with a smear of creamy sour cream. We were lucky to be seated before a queue began and I'm sorry you had to wait longer but with the plethora of dessert options, it would have been a sin to just leave. For dessert; an orange & almond cake, topped with chocolate, delicious and moist!  Tip - make a booking or get there early!

Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

sMXu8RHXnatPrdjo7cDbwQ.text: My cafe-owning husband had been raving about the Ottolenghi recipe book for ages now, this was the first time we'd been able to sample the food directly. As I understand it, Ottolenghi own several food shops around London; the Islington shop is their first sit-down restaurant.We got there on a Friday at 12:00 noon, and within 30 minutes the place was packed. You can walk in, order a sandwich and take-away salads, and be on your merry way.If you have the time (and the opportunity) to sit down, you go to the back of the premises where a long communal table and a few satellite 2-seaters await.The decor is very decidedly 70's retro; white-plastic everything with lime-green cushions, chrome standing lamps, the odd bit of fuchsia here and there. However they managed to put on the brakes before going too far, and the effect is entertaining without being eye-rolling.It's a *very* small space, and they cleverly went for the maximum daylight with as much glass in the walls and roof as they could.The overall effect is bright and airy with enough design employed to make lunch here feel like an event.Ottolenghi is all about the best and freshest ingredients, imaginatively used and presented to the customer in the most fantastic way. When you walk into the place, both sides of the front-of-house are stacked with the most jaw-dropping, eye-popping displays of salads and desserts you have ever seen. It's such a small premises, and yet how they use their food as display is simply brilliant. You want everything.The food has a very definite Lebanese / Mediterranean slant, and the menu is just chock-full of tasty salads, main courses... it just goes on and on. The menu cannot but satisfy picky vegetarians and carnivores with voracious appetites in one sitting. Quite, quite superb.Whilst I love my desserts, I've never been a huge fan of cheesecake. No longer, because the apricot cheesecake at Ottolenghi is quite simply the best dessert I've ever tasted. I'm going to say it again - the best dessert I have ever tasted; and if you ever saw my waist-line you'd know I've had a few desserts in my time.Friendly staff? Though the place was crowded, our waitress still found the time to answer our questions, discuss the food (she knew what she was talking about) and tell us a little about herself, not to mention getting us permission from the manager to take a few photos of the heavenly food displays at the front.From now on, every time I'm in London, I'll be dropping in to Ottolenghi without fail. Five star.

C7DylCg3Kq3iwz4u9IJLqg.text: great atmosphere also drink menu is great!

Qz6sOuCUSVW_G65xEWY9Cw.text: I don't plan on dying, but if I do I want the most beautiful words in the English language to be on my gravestone:"Tempura courgette flowers stuffed with ricotta and Swiss goat's cheese and truffle honey"

qrcm0cd7367R6YahB5jSlw.text: This was quite an experience! Best seared duck I've ever had. The octopus was heavenly was were the cold courses. Pork belly had a crunchy layer that tasted like no other. I highly recommend the lamb chops ass well. For dessert, the passion fruit tart was the most delicious tart I've ever had!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Passion fruit tart and mint tea
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Octopus
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

KDgp9cdMBBe1NhcJ64ys7Q.text: I thought I died and went to culinary heaven! Ottolenghi uses the finest selection of fresh organic ingredients in a unique combination to create amazing mouth watering gastronomic delights! The recipes consist of a diverse fusion of Mediterranean, Asian, Moroccan and Indian ingredients to create one of a kind dishes served in sharing portions similar to Spanish raciones.  Excellent wine menu and attentive service. We sampled the yellowfin tuna plate, sushi grade tuna sliced thin with a light crust garnished with a wasabi cream sauce. YUM! The Aubergine salad consisted of fresh baby greens tossed in a savory vinaigrette and complimented the tuna. The grilled sea bass with raisin salsa had a Moroccan twist and a spicy potato dish was fantastic. We regret that we did not have any room left to sample the baked and sweets menu but they looked almost too good to eat! It's a high end establishment with commensurate prices but definitely worth it as the food is of excellent quality and the menu is unique and creative. I am amused by the reviews from the locals because they are so accustomed to having so many wonderful dining options that they tend to be a tad jaded. They are so fortunate to be able to live in London and have all these wonderful establishments on their doorstep.It's easy to take these things for granted until you move to an area where you don't have these dining options. I can appreciate the uniqueness of Ottolenghi as there is nothing like it in Tampa Florida. Yotam Ottolenghi, the chef and founder of this chain of highly successful and unique chain of combination gourmet food shop/restaurant spends much of his time creating and testing recipes for these shops and his column in the Guardian in addition to TV appearances.

vj8sxGDUiESw1fikske69w.text: Just commenting on the savoury food, service and cramped seating... I didnt understand why this place is so hyped up. Food is of good quality but overpriced. The flavours although varied, dont compliment one another and it feels like there are many ingredients just added for the sake of making food look more varied and dressed up... Was disappointing for me..

LVGxZbga4TLKh1gyew0RIA.text: I *cannot* believe it took me this long to actually come here. I was missing out! This is an amazing gem: It looks like a bakery (all those pastries in the window!), but then you go in and see the platters of aubergine with yoghurt,  nuts and za'atar; the perfectly-roasted carrots with pumpkin seeds; the red & yellow beets with feta... And then there's a whole hot menu to go with.  The duck egg -- I don't know what they did to it -- was just incredible.  My friend and I had to pause our conversation entirely for the duration of the egg, and then had no idea what we'd been saying.  The five-spice tofu had a wonderful texture -- so silky! -- and great peanut slaw accompaniment.  This is *exactly* the kind of food I love to eat: Vegetable-focused, lots of thought but not over-engineered, wholesome.  I want to come back every night.

5_BX9r3bq2ria_wSTaP8vg.text: There's a lot of mediocrity on Upper Street - it's one of those areas where restaurants don't seem to have to try very hard anymore. Ottolenghi is a pearl amongst the dross, and at the risk of hyperbole, just about dished up the most delicious meal I've had in the capital. I snuck a seat on the communal table where I met a lovely brace of Kiwis and North Americanos.  I selected lamb which is served with an aubergine puree thing and some kind of chervil (maybe) - Yikes, who can remember all those Ottenghengish ingredients? I also had a wicked salad with spicy macadamias, gorgonzola, quince, and leaves. Just divinely subtle and interesting mix of flavours and textures. Sounds like slim pickings, but the salad was a reasonable serving. I followed it up with a vanilla and apple cake which is served with a gorgeous thick and cool custard. Eating alone, I had a chance to really savour the flavours. Two dishes, glass of wine and massive aforesaid cake came to £32 - incredible value for the quality on offer. Miam miam.

9nZQZpm23gcvj_IiA-jd0Q.text: We live about a mile away from Ottolenghi's Upper Street location, and I've walked past it and stared longingly in the window dozens of times. We finally booked a table for a Friday night (two months in advance - Fridays are popular!) and had such an incredible meal. I can't wait to go back. We had a mix of things from the kitchen and from the counter and all were truly magnificent. When I heard that Ottolenghi's next cookbook is going to be all about sauces, I was pleased and not the least bit surprised. Every single dish served with an accompanying sauce was different and interesting. The sauces didn't taste too heavy, but the flavors were complex and fresh and just all-around brilliant. The unpretentious dining room, kind staff, and clean, relaxed atmosphere made this such an enjoyable experience. I've recommended it to many people as it was one of the best meals I've ever had. I keep telling myself I'm going to stop in and pick up some things from the counter to takeaway, but the queue is always out the door so I haven't braved that just yet. But I will. Oh, I will.

h6sAgLPyXv2NSevRYJ9mEA.text: Came here on a Sunday brunch with the flatmates.Lady luck was on our side, as there was NO WAIT to be seated. Shortly after we were seated and placed our orders, the queue started forming and went out the door! This place is very popular - and rightly so.I ordered the bean chili dish and the only other order I remember is the North African dish that came in a skillet. You could tell in that there was thought and care given to the presentation of the food, it looked fresh and tasty when presented... and it was.The bean chili was great. There was bean & sausage chili served with a slice of blood sausage on top of fresh bread. This was paired with a fried egg and salad greens. The ingredients were fresh and paired well. Even the blood sausage tasted great, and I'm not usually a big fan. Overall great place to dine, especially when you don't have to queue. To be fair, the line did seem to move relative quickly, so don't be too disheartened if the queue stretches out the door.

58zTPZToZSUmW1T3v2iOmQ.text: We had been here back before Yelp UK launched, so I can't be as detailed about the experience.  I don't remember exactly what we had, but I do remember that it was the best of our meals in London.  Pictures will have to suffice.  Dining room is smallish and quite chic.  Food was creative and excellent.  US credit card was no problem.  Service was very good.

JBG5v9yMVFFPoSZHdkaRYQ.text: Had a fantastic dinner here a few nights back. Between the two of us, we split two cold and two warm dishes (they'll tell you to order five or six for two people, but unless you're really hungry, four + dessert should be fine). Colds were the steak and the tuna; warms were lamb and pork belly. For dessert, we had the apple cake and the caramel cheesecake. Everything the brought to us was fantastic... I'll definitely be back. Also, the design of the loo makes it worth a visit!

Eo9yu_BPnExf459Jh_pEMw.text: I have had dinner at Here before and it was very good. This review is regarding brunch. Online it says they serve breakfast until 1pm.I specifically called the restaurant to confirm they would serve us breakfast as long as we arrived before 1pm.When we arrived at 12:45, they said the wait was 30-minutes and we would miss breakfast. The hostess denied our conversation and the manager didn't make it much better, offering to serve us in the crowded waiting area where nobody was eating.How hard is it to scramble up some eggs? We ended up down the road at The Blue Legume which I would highly recommend.We will return, but how bout some empathy for some ex-pats craving some eggies.

9qX8TSk3dDtRAqHzZ4e6EQ.text: Dinner was arranged by mutual friends. I had not personally heard of this restaurant before. I must say that the food was outstanding. Presentation was good and the service friendly as well as generally efficient. However, it was the taste combinations which were unique, inventive and outstanding. Every starter and main that our table tried was excellent. The portions are not large - so inevitably, if hungry, you may need more that one main.Price wise, given the portions, I would consider this expensive but worth the visit and booking ahead (which is a definite must).

3TqqfDuYTqJd9wl54LBPOw.text: I could eat here everyday! Such fresh and tasty salads, amazing service and a great choice of gluten free foods and desserts

oFVNXQmNjh7p93KU-NDziQ.text: Wanna know a good joke? - One Sunday afternoon during the Olympics I thought that it would be great to eat at Ottolenghi...hahahahah!Right, forget about getting a table, but I circumvented the queues by simply ordering a take-away food. Having fallen in love with their salads at their sister restaurant (NOPI) in Soho, I knew went straight to the large salad box at GBP 15.90...and boy did the waitress make that worth the money: usually when you order take-away salads, they fill the box half-heartedly, but this time they filled it to the brim until all air was pressed out! Seriously, the box was heavy as a brick!I took the salad home, put it in the fridge and enjoyed it later in the evening...ahhh...a little bit of Ottolenghi at home!

_w5PhsSvvEcme6SKBGfEzg.text: A legendary place and it has all been said before however I do feel that one thing should be emphasised: the pasties cannot be beaten.   There are many different types and the ones that we tried (four between the two of us, I am ashamed to admit) were amazing.

zFBJs22Cn2qsJSEX_9TIgw.text: Best takeaway salad in the neighborhood! The grilled aubergine is to die for. Not for when you want a cheap meal. But just about as gourmet as takeaway vegetarian salad gets!

H0ZjBDGeHJJSxg4Bk6OMbw.text: The first time I went with my boyfriend we loved our brunch! He had the very popular shakshuka which is a dish of eggs baked in a tomato sauce and it was great. However, the second time we brought some friends (and had raved about it) we were disappointed. The scrambled eggs with smoked salmon was very underwhelming. The eggs were very under-seasoned and it came with a teeny weeny bit of smoked salmon. Boo =[

5IaN7XhCtU1ISrn_MRLbTQ.text: Didn't stop for lunch today  but took a cake away.The lemon mascarpone bombolone was not as I expected.  The outside was dry and the doughnut consisted of mainly filling which I didn't like the taste of much. I'll go back one day and try the main courses.  All the salads are vegetarian and looked very good.

s70I0OoYZHspl3eijJKh9Q.text: So good. As a vegetarian and a lover of all things Ottolenghi, I was pretty excited to dine here. It lived up to the hype. I had so many amazingly delicious vegetable options and I left full and content. The service is great and the atmosphere is too. I would go back in a heartbeat for another delicious meal.

iXoDSPrzshTdr63wYMX3HQ.text: This place is a MUST GO if you're in love with mediterranean food cooked in the best, freshest way possible.Be sure to book a table or come early if possible, this place is packed with people who knows what good food is. Yes, they do take their food seriously and they taste good because of that. Their menu changes slightly through the seasons, while staying mouthwateringly delicious. Grilled broccoli and roasted aubergine are both beautifully done, buttersquash and homemade hummus also tastes amazing. The slightly steep £11 for a salad IS WORTH THE BUCKS!!The excitement continues through their dessert table, with cupcakes, pies, baked goodies, tarts, cakes, chocolate and giant meringues. Overall, this place isn't big, but food is definitely rewarding for a long wait. The dazzling and divine food is worth to share. Always had a wonderful time here with my friends, and always leaving them with happy faces and satisfied tummies! TWO THUMBS UP  (and toes!)  FOR OTTOLENGHI!

xB8X7zUbdOfNIEnZrMyCFQ.text: Within 15 minutes of booking our flight to London we had reservations for Ottolenghi secured, that's how high eating here was on our list of priorities. My vegetarian girlfriend is kind of obsessed with the Plenty cookbook and so I was expecting a fully vegetarian menu. I was pleasantly surprised to find some meat dishes, and the tea smoked lamb cutlets were actually the highlight for me, although everything we had was fantastic. Lots of simple, bold flavors with an emphasis on quality ingredients. I loved the ambiance, just the right mix of romantic and laid back, with enough seating variety to work for large groups with the communal tables and small tables for two tucked away. The service was attentive and helpful, not nearly as pretentious as the price and quality would justify.And then there are the desserts. It's like they took a world class restaurant, and then added a world class confectionery to the front of the restaurant. It's almost too much. When we went in the front door our eyes enlarged like a cartoon character as we took in all of the sweets, and spent the time waiting for our table scheming about which desserts we'd get. By the time we had finished with our meal, we sheepishly admitted we'd have to get a dessert to go because we just weren't able to fit one more bite of food inside of us. This worked out great though and let us extend our Ottolenghi experience out to the next day.Reservations here are highly recommended, as a number of people tried to walk in while we were there and turned away.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. S'more cookie. Highly recommended.

ZEX-AkLwmhXZRmozph4M2g.text: The food is as good as it looks. It tastes different from everything you already tasted. Seeing the food makes your choice even easier.I recommend take away though as it is a bit over priced even though the food is of great quality (taking away is cheaper that sitting in) and the restaurant has nothing special as opposed to the dishes.

IwBNLFSKH0JADCyuK2JZyw.text: As you enter there is the counter area, full of cold savoury dishes as well as cakes and desserts with the dining room situated at the back of the space. We were sat at the end of the long, central communal table which is dim and candle lit in the evenings (there are smaller, separate tables for couples). We ordered a round of Kia Royales while we looked over the menu. Our waitress came over and explained that everything was starter sized, so we'd probably need 2-3 dishes per person. This was a bit scary, as the dinner menu averaged out to about £10 a dish and aside from the cost, I wasn't sure if it was possible to split a starter portion between 6?!The menu was split in to two sections, counter and kitchen with seven or eight dishes on each. The counter dishes being those that are on display at the front of the restaurant and the kitchen dishes being cooked fresh and served hot from the very capable kitchen team. As well as several bottles of wine we ordered pretty much everything on the menu.The Islington restaurant has daily changing breakfast, lunch and dinner menus but you can expect things like Glazed pig cheeks with apple stuffed tail and celeriac and barberry salad, Roasted aubergine with Iranian lime yoghurt, pomegranate seeds, spicy nuts and mixed herbs and Five spice crispy tofu with tomato and cardamom passata, braised aubergine and pickled lotus root, which I'm sure you'll agree all sound mouth-watering!Every dish was fantastic, beautifully flavoured and perfectly cooked but they really do mean starter size, the portions were an issue as we could only have a mouthful of each dish and not even that in some cases, there were only 4 scallops between 6. By the end of it we still had plenty of space for dessert. A few of us got up and wandered through the restaurant to scout the dessert counter and reported back. Again, these were delicious.

zFDOIXFB3fJgcCo1sr76Jw.text: We ordered from this restaurant as takeout as had heard it was very good and reasonably priced from friends. The food was delivered quickly and was very warm on delivery. The food was great at a good price, not too overpoweringly spicy but just the right depth.

GuXjbv5Dr-Fg2gJU_2XTlA.text: Tasty, but little greasy to me.. Not too many choices actually, I went there around 3pm, peas salad, pumpkin salad, cauliflower , broccoli, mixed cabbages ,potatoes salad and aubergine dish. I asked for small takeaway box, filled with broccoli salad, cauliflower salad and mixed cabbage,  the potion was really nice, with reasonable price. Broccoli was chunky and tasty, well cooked, spicy and full of garlic flavour, just like chinese stem fried garlic broccoli.  Cauliflower somehow more greasy than the broccoli dish, however well cooked, tender and juicy. They used lots of nuts, pistachio and almond, in their dishes. Not bad, more fun.  Mixed cabbage, very fruity, really funny, enjoyable.Dessert.   Mountains of cakes and tarts there. I bought pistachio lemon cake, blueberry cupcake and carrot cake. Carrot cake, good texture! Lots of nuts and dried fruit dices, light topping, feel the energy and feel healthy .  Pistachio one was so cute. Pitch of pistachio on the top of icing sugar, looks like elderflowers blossom on the snow mountain. The cake base was quite wet, unexpected. But still taste good. The blueberry cupcake, better go with coffee or tea, topping was really rich. Overall, a creative restaurant, good for family and group. Great for afternoon tea , light meal before dinner , pre-theatre dining.  Ps I won't say the salads there are healthy... =_=

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

vtYXCHeAlWtLnlMRG8wxBQ.text: i can't say i enjoy the lunch/dinner offerings, as i'm quite a bit of a carnivore. i also dont understand all the rage regarding the broccoli. but then again, i've only really been impressed with a veggie dish once in my entire life, so i've got a pretty high bar for a veggie dish.that said, the breakfast here is glorious. i love their croissant and pain au chocolat, even though i generally don't enjoy bread. my favorite, though... is the yogurt, fruit, granola plate. the granola is so nutty and delicious that i often make deliveries to my family in california. and the fruit mix is also delish!i'd skip on the breadboard, especially if you already have bread coming with your meal. the highlight for the breadboard are the dips, and i guess you can try the dips with any bread. but then again, i'm not a huge bread person...

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. breakfast menu
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. shakshuka. this is actually pretty good, except that i'm not a huge fan of labneh. i know... i'm such a party pooper..

fQ7yRBPn3mwSbunB072cvg.text: I went here with my cousin last Saturday at about 14:30 so it was pretty busy but we only had to queue for 10minutes. We both got a selection of 3 salads and a portion of bread to share. We both loved the food, super fresh and really interesting flavours. Service was great and overall a very enjoyable meal! Left feeling satisfied but not overly full, which is always good! About £27 for both before tip so it is expensive but must be worth it because I can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. A selection of 3 salads and a portion of bread

RtOkSd9Ut-eF42aFM5toNA.text: I first thought this was an over priced sort of tapas set up, it was so much more awesom-er. Food was fantastic. The veal was sublime but don't be a cheap-o, go for 2-3 of the £9-12 dishes and it will be well worth the money. My only complaint, 125ml wine is annoying, stop it.

umtFCSQpRZrcusgP9FDI5g.text: Yummy, Yummy, YUMMY. I recently left Tel Aviv for London and I was happy to get some Middle Eastern flavours delicately executed with a Western twist. It's a very sexy exciting cuisine, you can feel the thoughts of the chef  behind each dish. Like I would say about an art exhibition it was perfectly curated and both a pleasure for the eyes and the palate. Oh I almost forgot, the desserts are INSANELY good. Worth every penny.

I-HNDEUtDfWiXW_s0-TpNA.text: Caveat: This review is solely based on a takeaway salad.I stopped by Ottolenghi whislt working from home the other day.  I figured with all the hype, I could at least grab a salad to takeaway and bring home. At 17 quid, all I have to say is..meh! Though delightful to look at, the various salads simply were not the attack on my tastebuds I was hoping for.  I cannot pinpoint one dish of the various mixes as standing out or being particularly bad, but I ultimately didn't finish the plate as after finishing about half I simply was no longer in the mood to eat it.  I recently wrote a review of Pita Gourmet in Fitzrovia and they two simply don't compare in terms of taste and value.  That being said, I'm aware of all the rave on Ottolenghi for dinner and look forward to coming back again for a seated reservation and separate review.

w0d6F77pEaDM6tZsDwe5iA.text: The place is nice and the service is great. The food-it's good, but the "small plate" bullshit is ridiculous.GIVE ME A WHOLE PLATE OF FOOD!I don't go to a restaurant to sample half the menu. Also, just about every dish we ordered had a puree on it. Chef dude, step away from the food processor.From the photos I expected the cakes to be awesome. They were nothing special. The worst part was the price. It was crazy expensive for what you get.-----

SrqqqJ7Jf9YxBGo3BokmKg.text: Got here at 5:30 pm and we were seated at 6 pm without a reservation on a Tuesday night.This place was just absolutely amazing.   Nothing was bad - we had 5 dishes for 2 people.  In most American restaurants we get one appetizer and one main course and share - so 5 dishes may not be enough for 2 people with bigger appetites.

qU-s1O0FUWh_HnI6mZP15g.text: I really, really yearned to dine at Ottolenghi's once in my lifetime after digging into their cookbooks, and could make a booking for dinner at my birthday. So it was a dream come true, wasn't it? Afraid to say it wasn't. The online booking times speak for themselves, you can choose the requested time by the quarter of the hour, which sums up the atmosphere quite well. It was all about making the most (of turnover) out of the least (available space). We were directed in a hurry to our opposite seats with two larger parties right and left of us, which made it difficult to have any sort of conversation. And then we were left with the menue. No recommendations, no questions about likes or dislikes, forget about any sommelier advice regarding the wines. The food was fine, the wine too warm, the service minimalistic and the guests the kind of neo-folk-we-feel-the-place-and-wear-vintage-sari-blouses-and-Persian-jewellery-because-we-can-afford-it.Love the cookbooks more!

olBbRyrr5_4INwB4f9X22A.text: Perhaps surprisingly, for a vegetarian who often hangs out in Islington, I'm not the world's biggest fan of Ottolenghi. The salads can be superb and the meringues are second-to-none, but the overall experience is a bit chaotic for an establishment charging so much for the privilege of eating there. I've often had to stand in a disorganised queue for what feels like a very long time when about to hand over a hefty sum for salad. If you're lucky you can grab one of the pavement tables on a warm day and watch the world go by as you eat your very nicely-prepared food. But I'm not so keen on the canteen-style seating and the so-trendy-it-hurts chairs. Your best bet if you've not got in early enough to nab a good spot is having Ottolenghi as a take-away treat option.

Wufr-ktTkxPhgEOHj_9x4Q.text: Classic Ottolenghi, heartfelt good food, amazing cakes and sweets. Takes no reservations for lunch. Perhaps slightly more expensive than an average lunch.

FI1ykHi6-wp18XsSmKQ2FA.text: I'm giving Ottolenghi the benefit of the doubt with four stars, because I think everything that I had a problem with was entirely my fault.  Thus, I'm going to be brief. I plan on returning here soon, and will update my review accordingly.Atmosphere - 5/5Selection - 5/5 Friendliness - 5/5What I got for the price paid - 3/5Baked Aubergine - 3/5Raspberry Chocolate Tart - 4/5

Eh0_Rlmeuwv3uBphsHa0SA.text: I wanted to love Ottenlenghi. Adore it, marry it even. Everyone talks about how wonderful the food is. And how pretty the cakes are. And they're right. But goodness me the place is disorganised. On one side of the door is the savoury takeaway stuff and salads. On the other side all the (tasty tasty) cakes. In the middle? A massive queue of people waiting to be seated for the restaurant. Which means no one can see what they'd like to order, no one can get to the food they want, and the staff can't talk to you because there are people and prams and children, (we're in yummy mummy heaven here) in the way. Frankly I couldn't wait to leave, and we were only getting takeaway. While being herded about be the staff because well, there wasn't enough space to fit people. No kidding. But the food is good. £4.50 for half a sandwich is taking the Michael, but the cakes we tried were as tasty as they were pretty. My chocolate and hazelnut ricotta thing was too heavy and I didn't eat it all, but everything looked amazing and I'd try it all again. I just honestly don't want to come back at the weekends. I won't eat here, I'll pop in if I walk past during the day and it's quiet. But it's not enjoyable to be in here, and no amount of yummy cake will get my backside sat in a place I don't like.

M8PfN-dPURCkgzsWEAk7UA.text: Ottolenghi's is my most favourite place for brunch, lunch and and everything else in between. I can't resist the cakes here, also they have the nicest tarts, cupcakes and meringues. The apple cake is especially delicious; moist, flavoursome, with creamy buttercream filling. The slices are huge and every time I get one I swear I can't eat it all, but inevitably of course I do, because it's too damn delicious to leave! Since as I am a complete cake geek, I can be critical at times, but I really have no complaints about Ottolenghi's, not one single grumble. As they don't have a menu with them on, once you are shown to your seat, it's best to get up and go to the entrance (where they're all displayed) see what you want and memorize the name to later tell your waiter.The savory food is a Mediterranean affair and you can mix and match from things like 'Couscous and mograbiah with oven-dried tomatoes', 'Sauté of chickpea, butternut squash and chard, served with mint yoghurt' and 'Roast chicken with chilli and basil'. Everything is super fresh and you can really taste the quality of the ingredients in these mouthwatering creations. I think I'm in love! They also have a cookbook (anybody fancy buying me this for Christmas?!) and cookery classes every month where you can learn to create an Ottolenghi experience in your own home, although these don't come cheap at around £125 per class. The only slight problem I have is the table layout of a huge bench running down the middle, which often means you're sat closer to your neighbour rather than the person you came with who is opposite. This also means that when it's busy you can hear more of what the person next to you is saying rather than the one infront! BUT if you're lucky enough to bagsy one of the side tables for two then it's a fantastic experience eating here.

hnLn-g0JyKIXO3ONpwLMjg.text: The star off is sue to the very high prices and queue to get a table but the food is absolutely delicious! Hope to come again soon.

Sv2Ia-Fw6ibspE9zgFpxsA.text: We came from the States to dine here, and we weren't disappointed.  We reserved well in advance and had a private table off to the side of the community table.  We had some find veges, great seafood, and loved, loved, loved the food!

DU_l81h54-Knce7Mb3qpBw.text: A fan of this place? More like a stalker.Now that I've discovered the array of delicious edibles on display at Ottolenghi, they'll need to put some ground rules in place about my legal visiting rights. Especially since I literally live around the corner.Giving me a delectable selection of salads, mains and desserts not only to choose from, but to literally stare at, (and drool over,) is pure divinity in my mind. And no nasty sneeze guards to ruin my lunch buzz.Go on then Otto -- the K-Fed & Britney custody battle will have nothing on us once I've had my way with you...

SHFKlMmJBQyUIiFH54sdCg.text: We came in on a Saturday at 2:30 finding the restaurant packed with people and a 45 minute wait. We decided to stay around and it was totally worth!Standing in line we were admiring all the beautiful salads and bakeries that are put on display. Ottolenghi really does a wonderful work of making all the food colorful and inviting.For lunch we had a mix of 4 salads, between the two of us we probably tried about 7 kinds. They were all interesting in flavor and I would say they are all recommendable. We also ordered a side of bread since we had been enjoying the display of breads by the entrance. They as well were yummy.We round up our meal by sharing the vanilla cheesecake with nuts and toffee on top. If you are into cheesecake this is probably to your liking, for my palate it was a bit sweet.Overall a very good experience with excellent food, service and beautiful setting.

0ZJT3nVkXLvk3GAL-YoClA.text: Lovely.  The food was great and the service very friendly.We didn't entirely love the communal seating.  Also, the staff recommended we get a variety of dishes to share.  While that did enable us to taste lots of things, several of us might have preferred to fully savor and enjoy just a couple of dishes.  I especially liked the eggplant, the scallops and pig cheeks (!).  Everything was delicious, including the desserts!

DosHw_Qc5kILa24PGmseMw.text: It's embarrassing that I live 5 minutes from this place and didn't discover it until I read about it on yelp.Islington, and in particular Upper St, is chain central.  Technically you'd have to classify Ottolenghi as a chain as well, as there are four of them, but it doesn't feel chainy.  The decor is predictable:  that modern, spartan look that is so beloved of fusion restaurants everywhere.  I like the communal tables, especially when one gets placed next to four attractive young ladies.  The place was packed when I went there so the ambience is fantastic.Apparently the menu changes every day, and there is a selection of hot and cold dishes to choose from.  The servings are entree sized so you need to get 2 or 3 each, and given they range in price from £8-£11 this can add up.  For the most part, the dishes all had sharply defined flavors, and the ingredients were of a high quality.  I thought a few of the flavor combinations were a bit weak but there wasn't anything really disappointing.  Be prepared for the dishes to come out willy nilly (with cold dishes coming out first).Despite what everyone else has said, I was not impressed with dessert.  Yes, it does look cool having them all stacked up at the entrance, but in the end they are just cake and pastries.  I expected a bit more imagination.Another thing I didn't like was that we booked in advance for 7:30, but when we got to the restaurant we were told we only had the table until 9:30.  If you are serving two sittings, then you should tell me this when I call up, not when I get there.  They eventually came over and told us we could have it as long as we'd like, but it almost sounded like we should be grateful for their benevolent munificence.I have it on good authority that the waiters here are "hot", and this was certainly borne out by the fact that the four females sitting next to me would start giggling like school girls everytime their Israeli waiter came by.  I personally found the service irritating; this is one of those places where the waiters seem to believe you serve them and not vice versa.Definitely one of the better restaurants on Upper St, but relatively poor service and the dessert menu mean this place only gets 4 stars in my book.  Thank you yelp for bringing this restaurant to my attention!

sb2U0uq7BaAU4Ecs8WJUSg.text: There is a slight air of snobbery at Ottolenghi. But when your food is THIS good you have every right to be a snob! Hell, if I owned it I'd expect people to kiss my feet as they walked in to take their seats!The food is glorious and they know it. The decor is minimalist but a little sterile for my liking. The wine selection is impeccable.Highly recommended.

9DJj3O0KHFKGL9yfk5jGDg.text: Oh my...Oh my oh my! Stop it really, your meringues are flirting with me, no really stop it. It's not fair. I've just joined a gym and had a manky salad for lunch...and your staring at me like the cooked sugary egg whites you are...tart - slapper - floozy!I know what you're trying to do and it won't work. Sitting in the window watching me walk by, you heard me "Walk By"...I didn't give in, but oh how I think of your crunchy sweet crust...I have to go now

T-IqEYiZTlA2codlQ1LBQg.text: This review is for brunch take-away and eat-in tea and dessert.Brunch (price for 2, about 20 quid)Impressive spread of salads and quiches with a creative and modern twist.Tea and dessert (price for 2, about 14 quid)Varies each time I visit but typically fanciful and fun. The flavors are bold and as described. So if you order a chocolate cake, expect to get punched in the mouth with chocolate.The staff can be a bit flustered at times but all are generally well-mannered and attentive. Worthwhile place to visit, even if you don't live near the area.

9l2R06_R7lSCv4FEg8-sWA.text: Perfection.I've been here twice for dinner, and both times, it has exactly embodied my ideal wish for a restaurant.Did it just get romantic in here?  By night, the restaurant is beset with candles, and soft lighting beamed off the ceiling.  Apart from making the crisp white space more cosy, it makes everyone look sessuale.  I like!BUT LET'S TALK ABOUT THE FOOD. I don't think I've ever enjoyed food in a restaurant so much.Let's just stop to think about that for a second: enjoying food in a restaurant.  When the food arrives, you clap your hands with glee, because it looks so beautiful.  Ravenous, you stab your fork into the colourful, fresh melee before you, and then - food in mouth, you stop, and sigh a little, and with your mouth closed, make frantic "MM-MMTRYTHIS!" noises at your eating partner.  IT'S THAT GOOD!Roasted eggplant with confit d'orange?  Truly one of the most amazing flavour combinations I've had.  Roast peaches with young goat's cheese and radicchio... Courgettes somehow infused with buttery garlic, paired with basil and amazing pistachios.... Roast pork belly with perfectly crispy skin... A luminous, ruby-red loin of tuna, wrapped in nori and wasabi, with some crazyamazing salsa...This isn't just one of those restaurants that hits a really good farmer's market, washes the produce, and artfully arranges it on a plate (River Cafe, I'm looking in your direction) - this food is more labour-intensive, more flavour-intensive.  Their desserts are even better than they look in the window (quite a feat there); the wine list featured a whole bunch of wines I've never heard of, and every one I've tried is great, so, interesting wine list?To really confirm my approbation - upon arrival, they provide a range of breads, and some olive oil... the bread?  Completely, 100%, slow-fermentation, chewy creamy crusty PERFECTION.  Best bread in London!  You had me at 'bread'!  etc etc!

VOKGrW9sUlV_Nx9XgkC0_A.text: I think the key to any successful establishment is to make XL meringues, have a drunken game of pyramid with them, and stick the display right next to the storefront window.  I haven't seen one person walk by and not peer in to the pure white goodness that is Ottolenghi.Come on Yelp, we've all been wanting that half-star rating so give us those increments, now!!!  This place would've gotten 4.5 fasho, the only thing lacking is any space to enjoy all the delicious sweet and savories that come out of here...unless you're dining in and can utelize the high-end picnic bench in the back that is. While I first came in to taste these aforementioned mysterious, obese meringues...the ADD kicked in immediately upon entry and I was forced to rob the place of other goods.  The egg tarts are delicious, as well as the various muffins that they have.  But the most memorable thing I've shoveled into my gluttonous self is the quinoa with sundried tomatoes and sweet potatoes.  Absolutely mindblowing, fresh food - it is almost painful to see such gourmet stuff displayed out in open trays, a la school cafeteria slush.  I resisted the urge to jump in front of these silver housings and protect them from the nasties such as bugs and swine flu. Definitely a great place to get some dessert and top off a meal, or a quick lunchbox full of hearty and flavorful food.  Just don't expect a lazy Sunday brunch in here, since you'll most likely feel guilty about taking up too much bench space with your ever expanding butt line (thanks to Ottolenghi)

jgqkup8Nbh1IhX3jLMR4tA.text: What a lovely place to discover on Upper St - you walk in and are surrounded by delicious looking deserts on one side and lots of fresh vegetables on the other.  They don't take lunch reservations so there was a half hour wait, but the fact that the queue did not stop all afternoon long, is a really good sign!  Despite the popularity, they did not hurry us.  And I loved the fact that you could choose a main and salads - I love trying lots of different dishes so this was not bad value (12 quid for 2 starters and 1 main - at lunch).  Definitely worth a visit - the food is all fresh and healthy.  The chef Yotam Ottoenghi has some great recipes published in The Guardian and has his own cook book which I've heard has a some delicious, mediterranean influenced recipes.

hqnfwAKUavKCAJR_Mcy6NQ.text: Great spot....traveled from Colorado and was not disappointed.  Bit tightly packed with tables and thus noisy, but well worth coming. Recommended 4 to 5 plates from menu for two people and that was just right.  Spicing very different and lovely on each and every dish. If you are a foodie you'll be pleased.

icfk7itA8ZlohdLerArQmQ.text: This is a great place to go for lunch. The food is delicious, which i do not say lightly, and its definetely worth the price.The staff are friendly and attentive. The style of seating is a little crowded, not the place for a quiet romantic dinner (though apparently they are opening a more restuarnt type place in feb). A normal plate with 4 types of salad is enough to really fill you up. Each salad was well balanced, flavoursome and a joy to eat. The deserts all look amazing and the one i tried did not dissappoint. I would thouroughly suggest this place to anyone in angel/islington who is looking for a place that is dedicated to truly high qaulity food.

6IRT9aT7_ZBiPFt-8ND7Fg.text: Of all the good and great restaurants I've tried in London, Ottolenghi is my absolute favorite. It's pretty casual yet every bite is clearly well thought out with perfect balance. Everything is so fresh and full of flavour. I love what they can do to a simple vegetable. With just a few additional ingredients, they can transform anything into a star. You have to save room for dessert especially if macadamia caramel cheesecake is available.The room itself is casual with a couple large shared tables and a few for smaller parties. I personally love the clean whiteness of the place...it makes the food jump out at you.The biggest compliment I think I can give them is if I could eat this everyday, I don't think I would have a problem becoming a vegetarian.

dBDhDAj3saBh-63WUhEFxQ.text: Have been going here for more than six years. It never gets old and I always make the point to head over to Upper Street every time I visit London. The food is always inspiring and sourced using the freshest, local, and in season veggies. Prefer this to Nopi. Ambience is relaxed, long communal table. Also, fantastic array of desserts for those with a sweet tooth. Order lots of small plates to share.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

iOcq0J0JUDOJP-n-SyuLYg.text: Our annual trek to London of course included a dinner stop at Ottolenghi (after drinks at The Bar With No Name first - yelp.com/biz/69-colebroo…). At 8pm on a Tuesday we managed to snag 3 seats at the side bar without reservations. Hubby says I went a little crazy ordering off the menu. Maybe I did. I had brought a vegan friend who'd been starving her way across Europe on her holiday and I wanted to her to eat some good food. Luckily after her trip so far she was relaxing her strict veganism. So I ordered every vegetable dish on the menu - though not vegan they only had small bits of cheese.COLD DISHESGreen beansbroccoli/zucchini/­trufflesauberginequince saladbeetsOut of these our favorite was the broccolini and zucchini with truffles (of course!) though they were all really good. We were pretty satiated after this first round of dishes but it didn't end there!HOT DISHESpotato parcellambsea bassI forgot about the potato parcels! The lamb was really good. The sea bass was "meh". DESSERTSmincemeat piechocolate fondant cakeI ordered the mincemeat pie because my friend had never tried it before and what better opportunity than with Ottolenghi's signature mincemeat pie. It was good - for mincemeat pie (never one of my favorites). But the chocolate fondant! OMG! Total for all these dishes plus a house red and dessert hot chocolate was just over £100.

r2r5HO1YrUD0262WbwxVJA.text: Reviews here are not needed. The cook books and the countless reviews speak for themselves. I wouldn't be adding anything new that hasn't been gushed about. I just love love love this place and the recipe books.

VUMf_G3fwZlwdUK1OgsLwg.text: Great salads, filling and original, had to wait approx 20 min to be seated which was fine.Great afternoon hang out spot with the ladies-recommend!Service very friendly

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Desert selection
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Carrot cake

QGTmDEKoflQNwYYsdf0EwA.text: Ottolenghi is a "small plates" concept, which - to be honest - ain't really my fave. WHEN IT'S NOT AT OTTOLENGHI.  Here I'm just a broken record because I love all things Yotam.  Small fresh plates, especially in this week's London heat, were perfect.  I've enjoyed many a time - and Yelped - about Ottolenghi goods before (n.b.: Ladbroke grove-ish location and just off Kensington Church St., too), but never had I visited the Islington location for a meal.  But I reserved, and off I went...I NOMed:Selection of breads to start: my favourite the cumin-curry-ish bread? had some heatWater with ice (ice!)Salad with peaches and gorgonzola and candied macadamiasTempura-battered zucchini flowers with cheese and truffled honey (zomgz!)Pork cheek "schnitzel" with a bramley apple / yuzu sauce and a mini salad with pig ear (sure, yes)Each plate was 11 pounds/ish.  We had a late lunch so this was enough to leave feeling sated after our early dinner (not stuffed, by any means): the recommended number is 5-6 plates for two, so you can rack up quite a bill here.Of course I got dessert to go and sat in the grass and enjoyed my Ottolenghi among the grass and lounging Londoners (lemon polenta cake and marscapone tart, for those wondering).  Dang, i love love love this place/Yotam Ottolenghi himself/everything that comes out of his culinary master brain.Yelp note: the aesthetic is dreamy.  Never have I seen communal tables so elegant (the majority of seating is at a long white communal table, though there are some two-seater options around the perimeter of the resto).  Double bonus: nice wine list.

JaLApYCi1HdD1MXxSHmFXg.text: We have now tried both Nopi and Ottolenghi and Nopi far out shined on every level. I was really excited to try Ottolenghi as we enojyed Nopi quite a bit. The biggest difference for us was the service. The service at Nopi was extremely friendly and attentive but at Ottolenghi it just seemed out of sorts. We were told we only had the table for a certain time...which is fine if you are speedy with the ordering. We sat for a bit and waited and then someone came by and said have you been here before and are you familiar with how to order? Then instead of taking our order, he walked away. We then had another person a few minutes later ask the same question but at least he took our order.Although we didn't care much for the service, the food was excellent. We tried a couple of the counter dishes and a few hot dishes. The duck was amazing!Also note its a giant communal sharing table so if you are looking for privacy this is not the place for you.

pVsDNRpWi_PDt9zTpkAIXg.text: I'd more or less been restaurant stalking Ottolenghi via friends reviews and the very beautiful cookbook inspired by it (Plenty).So, when I arrived at and was told they could not seat me with "plenty" of space visible (forgive me, couldn't help myself) I was definitely a little sad. Turned out the whole thing was a misunderstanding because so many people show up at the restaurant wanting just dessert - there were available seats for someone ordering dinner! After clearing this up I was promptly seated; so make sure you ask. On to the food - it didn't disappoint. Just about everything I ordered, meat, sides, desserts, was fabulous. I especially remember an eggplant dish and the scallops main. For dessert the aforementioned case up front is a little overwhelming but don't be alarmed: I'm pretty sure you can't screw up.

AP0jFympfGOBDOWKO-JI-g.text: Best service and fresh food in london, would highly recommend it to anyone that wants uber cool, yet understated.Cakes galore!

DhE6PYnhdAKSdvTnBV-zxQ.text: Ottolenghi is another place where the value proposition for takeaway is probably better than eating in. I come here frequently to grab takeaway boxes where you can choose 3 salads for around £11.50, but you have to understand that their salads are not really salads, and probably best described as vegetarian dishes. Where you go wrong is if you try to order the meat, as they usually have a beef, salmon, or seared tuna, and that's accidentally managed to add another £6 to my bill on more than one occasion, and that was just for a small bite! Now that was an expensive lunch. My top picks of the salads are the roasted aubergine and the butternut squash. But I came here for dinner the other evening (where you can book!) and there is a whole other side of the menu consisting of the hot dishes prepared on site. We were advised that the plates are like tapas, and advised to get 2-3 each (I always lowball and so we ended up getting 5). Bread was complimentary, which was different than when I went to Ottolenghi Spitalfields for lunch and had to pay for it. The olive oil is delightful. From the counter, we ordered the roasted aubergine, which is poor value at £9 to eat in for a small portion, about the size you'd get as 1/3 of the salad box. And from the kitchen, we ordered the pea and mint croquettes, pan fried sea bass, char grilled tiger prawns, and roast pork belly. The pea and mint croquettes were particularly interesting, as you don't see that very often and you would have never guessed what was in it. I'd say of the meat dishes, I liked the tiger prawns the most, but all were delicious. And my favourite part of the meal is that they have a selection of orange wine here, which is an uncommon find in London! I'd only had it once before and we tried the A Demua, which was a bit dry for my normal tastes but it was nice to try something new. That said, dining in here is a rather expensive proposition, and I'm not such a big fan of the long table seating arrangement, where there was never a prayer of fitting all of our plates on our little allocated area of space, so my preference remains for takeaway.

DIWAmVpvm7KF9oaH0NSS4Q.text: Really inventive, delicious, Mediterranean sharing plates with a twist. The food is fresh (the vegetable plates might be Ottolenghi's strongest suit) and the flavors always surprising (in a good way). An eye-opening experience.I'm not a huge fan of communal tables, so like to book the single tables on the side, but otherwise, it's my favorite place to meet friends for a dinner date, or as a treat - especially if someone's visiting from out of town.

tPozg1bPhn4UGxVXYG18Bg.text: Went to Ottolenghi in Spitalfields, London the other day. We sat at a communal table which was fine. The food and service were both first-rate. The baked goods for dessert were out of this world

9B94OTxDjhdxRPbIh8JB7Q.text: My dad's old friend brought us to Ottolenghi because it was yet ANOTHER hot day in London and I asked for something light. I had never heard of the place, but I certainly have now.I ordered the small lunch selection of salads - 3 salads. I felt so overwhelmed by the options, especially as they aren't my traditional types of salads. These were the most colorful and exciting salad combinations I had ever heard, and I'll admit I was REALLY quite intimidated by a salad that didn't follow the recipe of greens + other stuff. In the end, what helped me make my decision was ordering all the POMEGRANATE salads:- Roasted aubergine w/ saffron yoghurt, hazelnuts, pomegranate seeds, mixed basil = DELICIOUS. Roasted aubergine (eggplant) was done so well, and it tasted much better than I thought it would cold. Delicious delicious.- Kohlrabi, carrot & red cabbage slaw, passion fruit & pomegranate dressing = quite good. I've never had kohlrabi, but I liked the dressing a lot, and this was the closest to the traditional salads I've had. Crisp and fresh.- Purple & yellow cauliflower with almonds, pomegranate seeds, orange blossom dressing = very tasty indeed. Not much else to say about it but I liked it a lot. The more untraditional cauliflower colours made it extra fun for me.In addition to my 3 salads, we also had a bread board, which was pretty delicious.ON TO THE IMPORTANT PART. THE DESSERTS.I have to say that the highlight was really the salads on this hot day, but the desserts in the window are so difficult to turn a blind eye towards.I had myself a delicious cake. I don't quite recall the name was. It was orange-y and so light and fluffy. oh it was so lovely. (EDIT: 2 years later I remember, it was the orange chiffon cake!)I'LL BE BACK!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Bread board
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. 3 pomegranate-themed salads
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. This is how they make you sit your bum down.

rgIn3dbdKG2D_jocsUhYPg.text: Ah, what to say that hasn't been said before! One of thee best restaurants/cafe's in London.Thank god for Ottolenghi, that's all I can add! Med/ Middle Eastern food at it's finest!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

JA6hIrZUj_qo4mlJwwWoGQ.text: Really good salad! Love the seasoning and never tried that before! But the portion of the coffee is so small...feels like it's much smaller than a regular size/small size coffee? Though the latte art is cute

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Broccoli,cauliflower,fennel salad, really good
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Salad
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Latte

z8JyCxmxM8lkh8Qj8CtbUQ.text: Ottolenghi brunch is highly situation dependent.  I came here for brunch on a Sunday last summer and my friends queued for about an hour before my still drunken self arrived.  The food and service were both excellent.So why 3 stars?  I think this is the perfect place to go on a weekend when you woke up early, went for a run, and want something healthy and delicious. Unfortunately, those days do not happen often for me. As much as I wanted to like this place, aubergine salad, broccoli, and quiche did not kill my overpowering hangover.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. quiche

Ee8VCdTxsxhLbsGDQVGJFA.text: Ooh, but that five spice tofu is nice! Also tried the roasted aubergine and the mixed green beans. Things were tasty indeed, as was the bread and o-oil. But I'd prefer lower prices for portions of that size. It's £10 ish per plate and they suggested 5 plates for a table of two.

6tq3TAY4hZY951SD7ZoMow.text: Yeah...so...my first time at an Ottolenghi restaurant of any kind and I'm not sure how I feel about spending £80 for a meal for 2 which was to all intents and purposes a collection of small plates.I DID like what I had. Grilled Aubergine with a massala yoghurt and pomegranate was sensation ale and one of us HATES Aubergine so a pretty good result.  The pork belly with kimchi was the star of the show.  But everything else was, while enjoyable, simply not very memorable.It all felt rather worthy and healthy and solidly adding to you five-a-day but I can't help feeling that plastic seats, white benches, pre-prepared dishes and not very attentive service was worth that kind of cash.We will go again, and I'm sure we'll enjoy it again but don't take your next hot date there for a meal if you want to impress. It won't.

6hMxSWPpXm3I_R-mOCjrQg.text: What a lovely place right in the heart in the  hustle & bustle of Angel. Ottolenghi is quaint and cozy and don't even think about coming here for dinner unless you make reservations. I didn't know this, but Mike (I think that's his name) made some magic happen and found us some seats near the front of the restaurant. Every dish here is meant to be shared and everything is a bit out of the ordinary. Everything on the menu raised an eyebrow making me question what exactly it is I was ordering but with the recommendations from our server, everything turned out okay. Since all the dishes are relatively small portioned, you have to expect to spend some extra dough for the experience and slightly bizarre dishes. Some things my friends and I ordered were the seared scallops and the yellow fin, which I thought were the two best. The Smokey Miso broth, Red and Yellow Beetroot, and Roasted Aubergine were good but they weren't as compelling as the other two.As for the service, I was blown away. Service tends to be quite sh*tty here in London, and the staff at Ottolenghi were pleasant in a way that made me feel at home in this city so kudos to them for that. They provide great food and service which makes it no wonder why they're rated so highly on Yelp.

Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Roasted Aubergine

tQNq64ENLKHrozAJHbEwfQ.text: Bread board and salads - Awesome!Good for light meals or decadent desserts.Very cosy (sometimes crowded) atmosphere.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. French Toast (Yes! This is ONE portion apparently!!)
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Sweet Potatoes, Slaw and Hummus

L3xBrd4B6fhkYFVFBUGyug.text: My husband and I met some friends here for brunch, and luckily we got there when there was no queue and were seated straightaway. (When we left, the queue was ridiculously long and I bet that would have taken ages!)I ordered the shakshuka, which was pretty delicious, and husband got some toast and cheese. The food all tasted extremely fresh and well made. I'd definitely like to try this place again!The seating isn't as private, but it's good fun to share a huge table with others. Also, I do wish the menu were a bit more diverse so that non-meat eaters could have more options!Quick, random note: What's with the bathrooms?! Frosted glass doors for co-ed...

FjfexSVKkBlzd2Opb2aXZw.text: Delightful! The service wasn't fantastic but wasn't terrible, the bread was really good, and the standouts of the meal were the broccolini, the smoked aubergine croquettes, and the apple vanilla cake. Ottolenghi does their veggies right!Also on a less popular note - I liked the bathroom, particularly the hand soap. Definitely grab reservations for this place! I'm a big fan.

XE_HO4XepmQ-UjRKAYsk2A.text: Drop what you're doing and make a reservation at Ottolenghi right now!! In the top 5 best meals I've ever had. I went to Ottolenghi for dinner on a recommendation and ended up LOVING it. All options on the menu are tapas size and it's suggested that you order about 3 per person. The food is made from the freshest vegetables and made in such a creative way. I ordered the (1) Pumpkin and puy lentil mash with fried shallots, goat's cheese and herbs, which was my favorite of the three (2) smoked aubergine and nigella seed croquettes with tarragon aioli, which was tasty - especially because of the aioli, and (3) char-grilled tiger prawns, tom yum sauce, kohlrabi and shiitake mushrooms, which was delicious and had more shrimp than I expected. This place is also very vegetarian friendly and makes vegetables taste so good. Definitely make a reservation ahead of time. Overall: AMAZING food, creative, lots of fresh veggies, a must-go.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Bread served with each dinner meal
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Smoked aubergine and nigella seed croquettes with tarragon aioli
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Pumpkin and puy lentil mash with fried shallots, goat's cheese and herbs

hwVcnZTHlxV_Vt1zIdXbtA.text: We loved it. Only one of our six dishes wasn't off the charts amazing. There are also great choices to be had, and we chose perhaps 3 vegetable dishes and 3 protein, (fish and two kinds of meat). Casual ambiance and friendly service plus a charming waitstaff make this an accessible and lovely night out. Try the orange wine! They definitely do a good job making you aware of it but it really is a treat. Can't believe I've gone this long without it.. I will admit to some bias overall as a huge Ottolenghi fan, but this lived up to my expectations after dreaming about visiting one of his restaurants in London for years. Loved it.

fpS9hK4NDJNnxGkviJTo9A.text: A trip to Ottolenghi is an absolute must when in London, especially if you're a fan of his cookbooks. Unfortunately, I didn't have time to try their a la carte menu (it's a small restaurant - maybe 20 seats - and there's often a queue for tables) but I did go twice for takeaway salads, which more than exceeded expectations. Plate upon plate heaped with delicious combinations - eggplant with herbed yoghurt dressing, Israeli couscous & quinoa with capsicum and rocket, roasted pumpkin w seeds and a dreamy tahini dressing... the list goes on. Also, the desserts...
