I'm not normally into sweets but even I couldn't resist their caramel and chocolate tart, which tasted as good as it looked - sticky, dark caramel beneath a silky smooth dark chocolate ganache in a short-crust chocolate pastry. Heaven. They also sell edible gifts too - jars of dukkah and salad seed mix, packaged biscuits and chocolates and of course, Ottolenghi's cookbooks. Perfect for a passionate home cook.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. A sweet tooth's dream
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. So many salads...
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Look at those Meringues!!

Lg5FiBSDdbN4JBEAa1SsdQ.text: Ottolenghi is all the hype these days for making vegetables sexy.  The menu is creative and a welcomed breath of fresh air especially since Brits arguably don't eat enough produce in their traditional diets.  I came here for a group dinner and loved that it was family style as I was able to sample just about every dish on the menu.  My favorites of the night included the petite lamb chops, octopus, and seared sesame seed encrusted tuna.  This must make me sound like a carnivore especially since I noted above that the emphasis is on produce, but I assure you these dishes were well-balanced by a generous portion of vegetables.  For example the octopus was placed on a bed of sweet corn polenta, topped with fresh corn salsa and a sprinkling of crunchy toasted corn nuts, the yellowfin tuna was paired with scapes and green onions, etc.  Whatever the case, the protein + veg pairings resulted in a nice marriage of flavors.Even the wine menu is unique, featuring a selection of orange wines, which is a variant of white wine where the pulp is left in longer contact with the skins during the winemaking process. Ottolenghi definitely stands out in the London restaurant scene, just make sure you have a way of scoring a seat.  We had a hookup help us get reservations but otherwise I hear it's damn near impossible.

A3y1NQgjzCwGNPfhzwdHKw.text: A review for their pastries:My friend lives right next door to this place, and the display of pastries looked amazing, so we decided to give it a try one day.We asked them what their most popular thing was, and it was the passion fruit tart.  If that was their best one, I'm not sure i would give the other ones a try. The custard in the middle was way too eggy.  There was barely any passion fruit flavor at all. Everything looks so fancy, but I think it is all presentational.  It was 3.40 pounds as well, which was pretty pricey.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Passion fruit tart

03tenmxHWTKkxP33HoPE-A.text: Quite simply one of the best resteraunts in London that we visited. Flavors are out of this world. So many fantastic dishes to choose from. I am so glad my sister introduced  me to Yotam and his many cookbooks!  This is one of the more casual locations yet the selection was endless and we left feeling satiated and happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

YLv9xu19pjQT9GY7VvGIZA.text: Had a fabulous meal here last week. Particularly good because we had a vegetarian in our group - usually the vegetarian gets to pick from a couple of choices but here, half the plates were available for him! Our group of four tried 11 of the 15 offerings the night we went and I would say 4 or 5 were stunners, and the rest were quite good. Even a dish as ubiquitous as beets with goat cheese was particularly tasty in its simplicity and freshness. And the pork belly had that crackling crispness that makes you sit quietly after you take a bite, and just enjoy the experience in your mouth. I don't really have a sweet tooth, so I can't say the carrot cake blew me away, but the Ottolenghi hot chocolate was the best I've ever had - not too sweet and with a deeply flavorful richness in each sip.The prices aren't cheap, but the value is high. I would recommend going with several people so you can try more of the dishes on offer. Also, be prepared to sit at a long table with other patrons.

53hKaYOnTbFqGP6s-gOJ0w.text: Yum.That is all.Well I could leave it at that but there is more that can be said on the joyful wonderfulness that is Ottolenghi. If you're too healthy to not salivate on sight of the amazing display of cakes in the window, I dare you not to be impressed by the oodles of salads piled high next to it. Steps to take you to Ottolenghi heaven:Step 1. Bag a table. It may involve queuing but my tip is to go for lunch - it's mostly the same food as dinner, but at a much more reasonable price. (NB takeaway is an option).Step 2. Pick your food.  At lunch this is mainly cold food from the counter but at dinner food comes from the kitchen too. I personally love the counter salads - usually you go for 3 or 4. You can inspect them and pick your order on how they look. They are incredibly vivid and colourful, and are packed with Middle Eastern inspired flavours. I personally love anything with aubergine or pomegranates. Step 3. Eat, enjoy, appreciate the scrummyness. Then think about eating even more food with dessert.  Step 4. Repeat steps 2 - 3 with the desserts on display.Step 5. Die happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Piles and piles of deliciousness
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. 4 salads = mealtime heaven
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Hello there!

qoHnPgEljJ9f5vV3ZoBScw.text: Fantastic deli style food, some of the most delicious salads in town. I had a mix of different things (highlight being the aubergine) and it was all good. Casual vibe, communal tables, well known owner .. I recommend you visit!

S8DyaSqeR9xdkJ9Q4qTOEg.text: Love love love! What a great place to have lunch when in London. I have several of his cookbooks, so I was very excited to go to one of his restaurants. The food was delicious, the set up of all of the food and desserts inside looks meticulous and great service! Would definitely recommend and come back!!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. My salad plate. Delicious!
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Bread plate!
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Hazelnut and ricotta cake!

fb_2nM_OgrfZ6jndD5fMYA.text: Yes, this place is worth the hype. Beautifully decorated. Low key in morning but hard to get in at night at their fabulous communal table or a private one.I have been here for all meals of the day. The breakfast is calm and lovely, with hearty egg/bread dishes, and sweet ones like muesli with tahini. The shakshuka is a bit oily and comes out piping hot but worth every bite. Dinner is the best, when the small (slightly pricey) dishes come from the counter or the kitchen. The vegetable dishes are creative and fresh and tantalizing! I will remember the smokey eggplant with tamarind yogurt, the broccolini with Chillin, the seared tuna with sesame, and the courageous with pistachios for long to come.I dare you to try to resist dessert (but don't!) as the cakes and pastries are all out of this world. You might want some to go. Service is perfect, attentive, helpful and kind servers. Not cheap but somewhat reasonable for the area. And unquestionably worth it for the quality!

rESroKsLuMTLKSXP6bHNJg.text: Food was great! Service was friendly and the food came out fast! If we didn't socialize we could have been out of there in 30 minutes! The seating style is a group style so there may be many at your table you dont know.  It didn't bother out group of three though! I had the free-range chicken with roasted peppers and potatoes.  For dine in, it is very simple.  You order a main course and the option of 2 or 3 salads, or you can order 3 or 4 salads instead of a main meat entree.  This menu style when we were there.  They were also all cold dishes - please keep in mind when ordering as it was a bit of a surprise. They also had a good selection of organic wine. The dessert was good as well. They line the windowsill with their desserts. If you dine in, you order the desserts through your waiter.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Financier with mixed berries
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Main course: Free Range Chicken with red onions  Side dishes: Roasted red peppers w/red quinoa and roasted new potatoes w/leeks

EunpeQuurC_WETpUWmBujQ.text: Ottolenghi is known for the pastries and salads and these are really nice ! But today we went for dinner and  it was amazing much more impressionable than the counter food.

Z0-HWT6uNbXBhzRzJ_DgaA.text: Like so many of us, I've been hooked in by the window display. Cakes, cakes EVERYWHERE! But then I got in and tried the salads and I officially fell in love. It might look like the most expensive salad in London when you see the price-tag on the menu (£17), but meat + 3 sides is plenty for two to share!! Skipping the aubergine would be crazy as it's the best I've ever tried in London (and I'm not the only one thinking so as our waitress pretty much shouted "the aubergine" when asked for recommendations!!). The cheesecake is pretty ace too. Oh, and they're currently doing Peanut Butter Smore's. You only live one, so go and grab one (or twelve) before it's too late! The staff is great and very attentive, I don't think I've ever had my water glass refilled so often without having to ask for it! And they let me stare at the cake for as long as I need to make my decision (aka a VERY long time)...cakeandwhisky.wordpress.…

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Cheesecake | Ottolenghi, Islington
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Peanut butter Smore's. Brilliant. | Ottolenghi, Islington
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Ottolenghi, Islington

0STeTkCkKxq3aN_9-uOiZA.text: I came here for a spot of quick lunch with a friend on a Wednesday. The window displays were amazing, with an array of oversized sugary goodies and chocolates. The place was rammed and I was worried we wouldn't get a seat. I only had to wait for about 5 minutes to be seated. The restaurant had a large table in the middle with smaller tables round the edges. We got placed at the large table (picture sitting at Wagamamas with people either side of you). Despite the close proximity and loud gossipers, I didn't mind - I had a good feeling about this place.The lunch menu offered a variety of cold meats and salads. I ordered a main (salmon) with two salads (sweet potato and aubergine). The waiter mentioned that their salmon was on the small side so they wouldn't be charging for the main, which was a nice touch. Who wants to go back to the office stuffed anyway? The staff were really attentive and didn't allow my glass of water to drop below the half way point so you can't die of thirst here! The food arrived pretty sharpish and the salmon was not small so I was impressed! The food went down a treat! And to top it off, the discount was a really nice gesture.I thoroughly recommend this place for a quick, fresh and tasty lunch!

0y2tsN8GUX3XKHH_JiM5hg.text: The window stopped me in my tracks.All those sweets, cakes, bars, puddings...drew me in.White as background color, so all the colors pop. NiceBig bowls of differing savories, all look great, fresh, colorful, well prepared.Gotta have something, gotta. A woman approaches, we ask to be seated and she says 'very soon' and it is and we sit and water question and menus and away we go.So many great things on offer. Confession time: I bought his 'Jerusalem' book because I loved the food I ate there, and even though I don't have to cook for myself (benefit of marriage, thank you Dear) I get very tempted to when I pick up and peruse through his book.Every thing we ate was great. Truly 5 star great. Well done, everybody, take a bow!The prices ain't cheap, this is a trendy and up and coming part of London, but it is very good value for money.Do yourself and your palate and eat here. It's worth your time, money and effort.Enjoy!

tb_snXDKmFOmVXBIKPL3Sg.text: This was easily my best meal in London. All our dishes were executed excellently and each showed a flair for creativity without going too off the rails conceptually. Perhaps my favorite were the lamb chops and roasted aubergines. Each both managed to add elements which differentiated, while bringing out, not just the natural flavor of the dish, but more interestingly the texture of the dish.

eslkbqsrdFNydnXYjUoYKg.text: I think this was then original first branch of the famous Ottenlenghi and I must say this place is still as popular as ever. Popped in one early lunchtime praying there might be seat free and there was one thankfully thanks to kind staff sorting.With a healthy January in tow I had my eye on a lovely salad (I had phoned ahead and they recommended ones from the cold counter being very popular). It was very good. Mix of lentils and aubergine that were flavoured nicely.Service was good and I'd like to come back to this local branch for an evening as I reckon the ambiance would be better. Not withstanding trying some more of the delicious food that I saw. It certainly is a place that is great for vegetarian healthy eats.

jIZcZ_MdDlxCqHmZ1r9_8w.text: Well, isn't this an absolute treat? First, you'll need a reservation. Probably quite far in advance. You've been warned, do make one. I must admit, I let my dining companions do most of the deciding in terms of food, wine, etc. (However, I definitely made my own dessert choices!) This is my preferred way to dine, especially with "foodies" and especially those "foodies" that were so kind to secure the reservation in the first place. I will say though -- everything that passed my very pleased palate was perfect. The menu is curated well, just the right amount of choice without being overwhelming. I particularly enjoyed the sea bass and the aubergine dishes, but all were lovely. We got good guidance from our server, and everything arrived at the right temperature, without taking too long. *This is a sharing restaurant. Non-sharers, be warned! The real treat though -- the DESSERTS (and the wine, but I'm on a low-wine diet until the baby arrives). The cheescake with rhubarb was a revelation. The coconut macaron? MARVELOUS. The Bailey's chocolate cake? I'd get drunk on that any night of the week. Such masterful desserts, I'd come straight back just for them. I will actually do that. A very reasonable £50/pp with 2 bottles of wine, about 8-10 dishes and 4 desserts. Quite a good value considering the high marks Ottolenghi receives. I'll be making my next reservation....RIGHT NOW.

R10exy0bATmtRd3GnN7uYQ.text: This place is a real treat. Pure white walls, minimal chic furniture and a dazzling display of fine cakes make this a classy visit. Expensive but its worth it. Their merengues are renowned but everything is simply mouthwatering - you'll take forever to decide! Service is very helpful though.

dCSjeByjQtFAnfOSCigS8g.text: The food in this cafe is really good but it's not cheap and with a big table that everyone gathers around, it can be noisy and feel a bit too cramped for my liking. If you go in the morning they have brightly coloured dualit toasters on each table which looks really good and guarantees your toast is hot when you get it. The coffee is very good, cakes are amazing and the meringues (I think these are their signature piece) look incredible and taste very good indeed. They do great salads at lunchtime, they use the best ingredients and I guess that's reflected in the prices.

NKbasHa9geq3OkXoSZfjGg.text: Beautiful food for breakfast, lunch or dinner...though more expensive for dinner. Always busy, so don't be surprised by a 20 minute wait...rest assured its worth it.

xMB_d4TNnlkywUImHSLdSQ.text: I love this place.The coffee was great and I impulsively purchased the Aubergine salad with a saffron yoghurt dressing with pine nuts and pomegranates.A weird combination but it tasted spectacular!!The lady, who I presume, was the duty manager was really lovely and friendly.The other 2 male waiters could be a bit more friendlier and less bored.But other than that this place is just Fab!!

CVaMbCEPJmOxyZwUC4_qtA.text: Sadly Islington is rapidly becoming a facsimile of every other high street in Britain with a dozen ubiquitous and soulless brands parading their tawdry wears and forcing a mono-cultural imperialism on our land. But rejoice, for Ottolenghi bucks the trend! Yotam Ottolenghi is a culinary genius and an advocate of Slow Food, ie he makes things on the premises, using good, clean and fair ingredients and he really knows how to cook. It is both a place to pick up provisions for takeaway e.g. amazing cakes, wonderful bread, sandwiches, home made crossiants, the best meringues in the world, amazing salads full of fresh and exciting flavours and so much more. Alternatively, you can eat at the long communal table and enjoy breakfast (a toaster is brought to your table and a panoply of amazing jams and fresh bread), lunch or dinner. The menu changes regularly and features local, seasonal delights with a largely though not exclusively vegetarian bent. It may be grim up north, but with Ottolenghi at least it's also yummy.

aS89wwTTQXkvOpvCI79zsA.text: Popped in here for a few breakfast treats and had an outstanding parmesan twist, lemon and marscapone tart and double chocolate cookie, plus some orange juice (not all at once!). The quality really shines through in the rich taste, perfect textures and general freshness. Staff were also very nice and helpful. Definitely the best baked goods in a while and although it's very expensive you do at least get something great for your money. I wouldn't hesitate to come back for more, and would be interested to try the restaurant proper as well.

1gxyhPwdIdiE9R9X8tUqUg.text: I'm bummed that I hadn't heard about Ottolenghi until now. My friends who were visiting from the US and avid fans of Yotam Ottolenghi  insisted on coming here for dinner even though the only table we could reserve for 4 people on a weekend night was at 9:30PM.Upon entering the restaurant, I saw a huge display of over-the-counter dishes including some cold meats, vegetarian plates and an extensive and beautifully displayed selection of desserts. I also noticed that the restaurant was still completely packed at this time of the night and more people were coming in for their late night reservations.Shortly after we sat down, we were introduced to the menu by a very helpful and friendly staff and some complimentary bread. The menu changes from time to time and features no more than 20 items that come in tapas sized portions, half are served from the counter (aka cold plates), while hot dishes are made to serve from the kitchen. It was recommended that each person order 2-3 items.The highlight of the night were the cold dishes we shared. In particular, the roasted aubergine with zhoug, amba, tahini, and pita croutons were the best I've ever tasted. The flavors were surprising, exotic and inventive. This was true for all of his other dishes. The mozzarella di bufala paired with peaches and grapefruit is also a must-try. A spoonful of the creamy cheese and grilled peaches had a well-balanced and unique medley of flavors.For the hot dishes, the pork belly is a must. It was very well seasoned and the crackling pork skin was very crispy. The mango and pickled ginger that came with it helped to provide a balanced palette of flavors and cut the fattiness of the pork belly. We also got the goat which was delicious and not gamey at all. The medley of mushrooms was incredibly flavorful and exotic. I recommend getting more bread to dip in the mushroom sauce!I was pretty full after the hot dishes but we knew we couldn't skip dessert. After going up to the display and inquiring about every dessert they had, we settled on an apple and raisin slice, lemon and poppy cheesecake and a plum meringue. My favorite was the apple and raisin slice. It's sweet, delicate and flavorful. I recommend adding the complimentary vanilla custard to this!Overall, Ottolenghi's dishes were yummy, inventive and exceeded my expectations. It's definitely a must-try in London and I'll be looking into NOPI (Ottolenghi's higher end restaurant) after this!

swJgDbxkQB0gAH33g6USZA.text: One of my main reasons for traveling to London was to try an Ottolenghi restaurant. Maybe I hyped it up too much, but my experience at the Islington location was subpar for the caliber of this place. The restaurant itself was tastefully decorated and modern. The staff were cold, impersonal, and seemed always rushed for the low number of patrons. The food, although beautiful as ever, tasted bland and left a lot to be desired. Maybe it was a one-off but it steered me away from trying it for breakfast the next day.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

JBIvfSie4orwBNouVl2cUQ.text: --- American Tourist  --This review is for BREAKFAST.I have ham and it is very salty. I do not like it. But my wife has the salmon and she loves it. Coffee is very strong, watch out. We love the unknown berries sauce and nut sauces that they put on the table for the bread. The is the best part of the breakfast.We like the salad lunch much better than the breakfast. Service is great! Food is so so.First time to try, it is ok, I won't do  it again for the breakfast.

tKZs1D-wpuxnsbftMfwXvQ.text: Kind of bummed it didn't live up to high high expectations. And they did nothing for my birthday :( (Nopi surprised with a free gelato at lunch time) It seemed everyone had the ugly but tasty and smoky aubergine, the scallops with fried shallots and the beef shin in pastry with endives and tomato.  All good but nothing mind blowing.  The rum and chocolate fondant was incredibly rich and decadent, probably the standout of the night, and the lemon cake was devoured by my daughter.  Still love the cookbooks :)

xeUliidZO8I0cGbDsCKrMw.text: Okay so this place at first looks like a bakery shop but there is an entire restaurant in the back. The brunch menu is bomb! I recommend the scrambled tofu rose harissa on sour dough for a good vegan brunch option. The service is pretty good and the food just tastes so savory.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled tofu and my friend got the corn cakes and eggs which she said were so good.

0brJ0_TstRx1-zwiSmx43Q.text: There really is nothing wrong with ottolenghi. The only but you could find is price, but to be honest, for the quality of the food you get, I think it's well justified.I've been here many times throughout the years, but I recently called in to pick up a few cakes for a friends birthday. I called ahead to make sure I could come pick them up after work (and that they'd still have a good selection). They confirmed both and I rocked up at 7pm on a Tuesday to find a full selection of sweet treats still looking lovely and fresh as always.I got the classic flourless bundt cake, a must. I tried the caramelised pineapple cheesecake - gorgeous and super fluffy. One of my favourite new discoveries was the mascarpone lemon tart (but it's a lot smaller than the other two or so it seemed). The last cake was the pistachio polenta mini loaf. It wasn't my cup of tea personally, didn't like the texture or flavour as much as the others, but it was still good.4 cakes came to around £17 so, again, not the cheapest in London but if you're going to sin might as well do it in style!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. 2 veg plates
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Crispy pork
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Pastilla- phenomenal

zEafRA7TTBwgF-DAXVkHpQ.text: High praise all around. We made a reservation and so were seated at a private table. While the location was indeed nicely set off from the communal tables, it seems there was on this particular evening a communal table suited for families - those with children 6 and under - and another w adults only. We were beside the former and thus the noise level was quite high. That being said, the food and service much surpassed the slight disturbances to our side and we were absolutely thrilled with the experience overall. The vibe is both casual and sophisticated with a side of quirkiness. Our server was a gallant fellow who was warm and patient, and advised us to order 4-5 of the dishes. Not one of the items were familiar so we shot in the dark and selected a radicchio salad, the smoked lamb rump, cornish squid stew, and a cool turnip plate. We paired this w some orange wine (a first) and ginger beer. A variety of fresh bread slices were offered w extra virgin olive oil. I cannot say enough about the flavors. Inventive. Whimsical. Unctious. Surprising. The radicchio came heavily seasoned but it all worked with cubes of watermelon to really bring a punch of freshness to it. The turnip plate was incredibly flavorful and had me wondering if I had in fact ever eaten turnip properly because this was fantastic. I never order lamb as I consider it far too gamey but I thought if there was ever a place to try it, this was it, and I was not disappointed. It was perfectly medium rare and delicate and tasty. The cornish stew was a bit of a wild card and I avoided it for a bit as it came out looking like steaming black pudding but once I had a spoonful, I was cleaning the bowl dry. YUM. We rounded out the filling yet well portioned meal w the laphroaig and almond and orange cake w vanilla cream. The dessert was probably the least innovative and a bit dry but I concede it might have been a judgement relative to the truly unique and well executed dishes that preceded. I've already made a reservation for 2 weeks out at another location. I intend to try them all!

3mE0sg5giXgfw25YbP_t0w.text: Definitely pricey but yummy! Fresh salads and dishes. Minimal hot entrees (we got the fish) but really tasty!!Amazing service and very kid friendly!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Cake was yummy!!!

v2ujGxrVS1s6trnAaRU_pg.text: Although the food was good and the waiter super nice , I wouldn't come back not recommend this place. Bare with me :The premise here is you get a ojetes of 3 or 4 salads or a main with 1 or 2 sides. They stop serving hot items at 3 pm so forget half the menu options , you are left with roast beef !!! ( yey ... Not ) Moving on , they have a limited tiny menu The salads are :Roasted broccoli Coliflower slaw with mango Bean salad drenched in oilRoasted sweet potatoAnd 3 more ....The can accommodate food allergies but they can't give you dressing on the side so there you have it !!!The waitress was rude and condescending beyond belief I am so glad our waiter was so nice and polite !!!The place is cool with big tables  and funky furniture but the prices are very very high for  the portions you get. There are olives and hummus you can order as appetizers. The desserts and cakes looked amazing but we passed. I has a cheese crisp which was great but man !!! 3.40 ????? Are you kidding me ???? They brought it to the table because I saw it on my way in but didn't see the price ....Never ever ever ever ever again

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

-LjuREwE1CvT0sZxffYMxw.text: I stopped in twice for breakfast on a recent visit. I left very impressed both times. They have quite a menu for breakfast and they also have some pretty good coffee options and amazing pastry.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

2IWiTZMJvNz_L3weej1h2w.text: This restaurant is so fantastic. We booked a table so we got a table for 2, though you sometimes get sat at the big communal table. It's fine but I prefer the privacy of the individual tables as you are quite close to other people on the communal one!The food is so creative and interesting (and fairly healthy). Definitely get the ricotta stuffed courgette flowers. I LOVE these. The rest of the menu changes a lot but you can see the cold dishes on the counter and then they have some hot dishes from the kitchen. Everything was fantastic. King prawns were perfectly cooked with a delicious sauce. The roast aubergine had a great texture with a yummy feta yoghurt. Tip: Save room for dessert! The baked goods are outstanding. We shared a delicious apple and maple icing cake and a hazelnut cake. Both so moist! We got four more desserts to take away as we were going to a bbq the next day - they were all fantastic - especially the rum and choc cake and carrot cake. Go Go Go!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. My favourite. Tempura courgette flowers with ricotta. Dreamy!
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Fantastic king prawns with some kind of mandarin sauce
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Pink grapefruit with roquefort yoghurt and endive. Personally found this one a bit strong but fantastic flavours

cQeFBu_p7aYSGf-3nTfcFQ.text: I came here on my last day of my London holiday, and I'm kinda glad because I don't think I could have brought myself to eat anywhere else after this. I popped in around 11:30 to pick up a takeaway box of salads with the intention of having it for dinner after my spa afternoon. It was super close to my flat, but is absolutely worth going out of your way. The best vegetables I've ever had in my life. It's not cheap, but the small takeaway box is a very filling meal. I especially loved the eggplant and the sweet potatoes.I also grabbed a piece of a plum tart with almond paste, and a piece of ham and stilton quiche to have for breakfast the next day. Both were super delicious, although the stilton was a little too much when I was in that transitional still drunk/verging toward hungover state at 4am waiting for my Eurostar train. In better circumstances I would have devoured it.Go here. Now. For me.

xtyNw7dBGBMEtiov2gIqOQ.text: Amazing storefront full of beautiful pastries, drew me in. I had no idea they served a sit down lunch but my spouse and I are so glad we discovered this place! We then reserved a table for two for dinner later that week. Dinner was fabulous! As a cold plate, we got the tuna tartare. The hot plates, we got the mackerel, and the octopus. Dessert was the custard, chocolate tart, cranberry cheesecake tart. Everything was really, really flavorful! Service was pretty good. Try to get the individual tables along the walls for better conversation-ability.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Sweet, fruity thing!
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. More chocolate dessert!
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Seared tuna yumminess.

O1119oQJCibCGHbmwY9DnQ.text: American on business trip - stumbled on this close to my hotel. But was so excited to eat at a restaurant for a chef I owned a cookbook for! (So I was already biased to like the place)Service was great. Our waitress was attentive with a great sense of humor. Food was good, high quality ingredients, small portions but great for sharing. Good wine menu at reasonable prices. And location is great, close to tube stopDefinitely worth checking out!

L-6YkaFPByIOfX7cekiA-g.text: One of my favourite places ever. Ottolenghi has fresh, healthy food and it's super creative to boot. It's good service even if you have to wait to be seated, and you likely will. Ottolenghi is no secret around upper street. I only wish I still lived in London so I could go more often. It's a go to spot every time I visit.I've been for breakfast, lunch and dinner, and I've enjoyed everything I've ordered. The salad plates stand out for me - they're really creative and you feel good about yourself after. Their baked goods are unbelievable and beckon you from the window, and I've tried a bunch at this point. I recently had a lemony polenta desert that was amazing.Prices are reasonable too. Doesn't get much better than Ottolenghi.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Scrambled eggs with rose harissa (I subbed the tofu for eggs)
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Shakshuka

cOWD8ePV5fFU_OLQFLv_cw.text: I decided to check out Ottolenghi since it was close to the hotel I was staying at.  After 5 days of the traditional English breakfast, I was ready for a change.  I had heard of Ottolenghi from a New York Times article, so I expected it would get busy on a Saturday morning.  I timed it well by getting there as soon as it open and had my choice of seating and by 9am the place was getting closer to filling up.  The atmosphere of the restaurant had a Scandanavian/mid-century modern feel to it.  There's 2 communal tables in the middle and there were a couple of families with young children there which made the atmosphere even more enjoyable.Service was attentive but not rushed.  I ordered the shakshuka which I would describe as a North African version of chilaquiles.  It was perfectly done.  I also got a pastry to go so I could have it later in the day.  It was fantastic as well.  The only reason I didn't give the place 5 stars is that I witnessed a person next to me order their eggs "over easy".  The server didn't know what that meant but made sure they put a note indicating they wanted eggs "over easy. The eggs came back "over hard".  In my opinion every line cook in the world should know how to fry eggs in the 3 common styles "over easy" "over hard" and "sunny side up".  However is you order what's on the menu, I don't think you'll go wrong, and the menu items are a big part of what makes this place special.

pD8To8aDv78U9M_dxKLHeQ.text: So yummy! We were so excited to come here and it definitely exceeded the hype. The drinks were fantastic, they even had a fresh fruit smoothie that my daughter loved. They have the best vegetarian options! We shared 3 cold dishes, all phenomenal but the highlight was the cabbage slaw with crispy onions. We shared four hot dishes, and the fourth was our second crispy beef because we had to order another! We then shared an olive oil cake and a chocolate caramel tart which were out of this world. The atmosphere is lovely, the service is fantastic, and the bathrooms are clean. What more could you ask for in a restaurant?

tFYHTiwgwIeVKzLuVBP8iQ.text: Made dinner reservations in April for a June 7:30pm Fri time slot. After so many people raving about this place, I had to bite the bullet to wait a couple months and try it out. It lived up to all the hype so I was happy to have finally tried it. I thought the food was tasty and the ambiance was great. I didn't mind the long table at the center. We were at the very inside end of the table so it was nice not to have a free side. The food- definitely well made and ingredients were perfectly put together and tasted so balanced and gooooood. I couldn't get enough! The cold dishes were surprisingly good because I didn't think that something that is out on a massive spread at the front of the restaurant could be that great. But it was. The steak, tuna, and aubergines were my favorites. I was skeptical about the steak, but it was good even cold! The dips that were paired with the steak and tuna were perf. I wasn't crazy about the beetroot, so I'd skip it (you are, after all, spending £9-£11 for these small little starter plates where elsewhere these could be main prices and a lot more food, so pick your favs....we wanted to try everything so we took the hit).For the hot dishes, must have the lobster dish and quail. The quail surprised me because I thought it would be majority bones, but it was nice and meaty...for quail. The mackerel dish was interesting. I liked that squid ink was used for this dish. For dessert, had the orange cake and it was good. I'm not a fan with desserts or chocolate mixed with any type of orange flavor, but this was delic. Also ordered a dessert wine (Ramblis dessert wine, £5), and it was Tiny. I get that it's dessert wine and it's not filled like regular dinner wine, but I felt like there was barely much to drink to taste, sip on, and enjoy. I would of ordered another cake dessert if I would have known.All in all, this place is good. It's clearly proven itself for it's food and cakes and it's won me over for sure. The only thing is, is that it's pricey. I would maaaybe come here on special occasions, but for the amount we paid and the small little plates, I'd rather go to my other "pricey" places that are much worth it. But it was great to try! I recommend it to any first timers. *Make reservations (for dinner)!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Tuna (cold dinner menu option), 10.8
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Beetroot (cold dinner menu option), 9
Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom. Dinner bread

vb_c8cuNEb_eSNlUf2xXng.text: Simone literally read my mind! I asked him to surprise me with a drink.  Bartender literally read my mind! He came back with the drink that I had ordered at 3 other London bars, none of which had bartenders who had heard of the drink much less knew how to make it. I was in heaven!  Definitely worth trying this place out.  Thank you, Simone!

a2OGu1_1J1JUd4WM-ewOPA.text: I love Ottolenghi. Its a mother of a name to spell and almost as difficult to say, but its a great little place. Bit pricy mind you though.I bought my mother for a bit of late lunch on a Monday afternoon, and we had a very civilised hour as we were wined and dined in the lovely stark white minimalistic restaurant cum bar cum cafe cum take-out place.The menu isn't extensive, but the main meals looked tasty, and the salads and cakes on display at the front of the shop always look amazing, so its quality over quantity for sure.We shared a selection of salads (they had run out of a few things, but no problemo kind waitress, it all looks so damn good and health-giving that I will happily chow down on anything and everything you stick on a plate in front of my face) and breads, drank a nice cold glass of white wine and finished off with a couple of their famous cakes.I love the cakes. I liked the salad and breads and wine, but I LOVE THE CAKES. Come here and eat cake. Cake. Cake. Cake .

CcjPp_9KPoZE_XR1h6QF-w.text: Came here for breakfast and I spent the first five minutes picking all the bugs out of my fresh mint tea. Bleugh! However, the salads and cakes stacked at the front looked delicious and the staff were very friendly. Not Much choice for a savoury veggie but I had the scrambled eggs, which came more like an omelette, but tasted amazing.

30TRzM5xsWRi8h-S2NsX9w.text: Small, always quite crowded, but worth every visit. You will never miss it when you walk past the front of this delicious little restaurant: where on one side a buffet is laden with a mouthwatering range of different cold vegetable and meat delicacies, and the other side are plates and plates of desserts of all shapes and sizes and colour. If you have a love for food, this is a place you need to try. You can clearly see the seriousness of how the food is presented and the amalgam of ingredients used for each dish.  All made from scratch, their lunch menu of cold dishes are stunning. The dishes change constantly, and include such things as, 'spiced lamb and apricot filo pocket, served with mint yoghurt', 'seared lamb skewer with grilled spring onion, and tahini sauce' ,  'young Pecorino wrapped in Parma ham and rocket, with Lavender honey'. They also have a take away service for both the desserts and buffet, as well as a catering facility. Just going for a coffee and one, or two of their desserts is a rewarding experience, though maybe not for the waist line! Their carrot cake is scrumptious and their cupcakes, large and spongy. Their breakfasts are delightful as well, where I once had a croissant and cappuccino, and a huge plate of scrambled eggs served with a side of watercress, with the the nicest sesame oil dressing. Now I must try their dinner menu which looks just as good as everything else Ottolenghi has to offer.

KoGzNWKBAZhHwTTb6Q5Prw.text: i recommended the spot for my out of towner sf friends.  i had been to ottolenghi a few years back with friends and quite enjoyed it.  i made the appropriate reservations, but had to decrease the party.  i stopped in (it's only a few blocks from my flat) a few days beforehand to left them know.  i literally had to wait a good 10 minutes to have this done.  i must say the staff are very attentive to those clients coming in to purchase from the counter.  despite that, i still enjoy the food at the ottolenghi and my friends did as well.  we ate:- fried cauliflower garnished with pomegranate and lemon- french beans with figs and herbs- baked peaches- seared beef fillet x2- sea bass over puff pastry- chargrilled asparagus over jalapeno cornbread- egg over duckso otto recommends 3 dishes per person, but having eaten there before i told my crew to under order.  we ended up with 7, which was plenty and we HAD to order dessert.  we went with the chocolate cake and the carrot cake. delicious!  i'll be back for a little take out.* i have to give service a bonus when seated.  they accidentally gave my g&t to my fellow diner and quickly produced a fresh one for me after thirsty diner dug into mine.  he ordered a grey goose soda.  honest mistake rectified.

D8alSWQpgqLcjwnnikHPSQ.text: Everything I've had here is delicious. The food is inventive, crisp, fresh and oh so tasty. Everything from the beef to the salmon to the brunches are amazing. Plus, there are always sweets to takeaway. I'm in love with the lemon mascarpone tarts. Only downside is that it's a bit pricey. I'll definitely be back though

z45Cuzwgw2N2707DR9sgdQ.text: We found ourselves at Angel after a walk along the canal and in need of a spot of lunch, thought we'd chance it at Ottolenghi.  I was expecting a long wait, it being a Sunday lunchtime, but perhaps with the Wimbledon final on, people stayed home... we managed to sit almost straightaway, though the place was pretty much at capacity. Service was quick and attentive without being intrusive - had a great casual feel.  The meals were great - my tuna was well cooked and very nice while my dining companions had the chicken and the lentil burgers, both of which were very good.  The real stars of the meal were the salads, though - very fresh and flavourful and left us guessing what might be hidden in there.  Desserts were also good - one we'd picked had sold out by the time they got to us but the replacement choice was as tasty as the other looked.  For seventy pounds for lunch for three (without wine) it's not going to be somewhere we go every week but certainly next time we're in the neighbourhood.

iqG7mWONlaLz-jWPDkXhhA.text: Cute space in Islington with excellent breads and cold bar in addition to the kitchen. Service leaves a lot to be desired though, and they've been docked accordingly.

vbd1iYJtzJjSrJCL29pVNA.text: I call it yummy mummy central !Its amazing that all these mummies remain so yummy with the great array of pastries, but that may be because of the  Salad Platters !The salad Buffet is torture for someone like me because you walk into the restuarnt and have beautiful platters of these amazing salads and cold meats  and then you have to choose which three or four you want. I usually want all and have to ask the person I am with to choose. What is torture for me but great over all is that you can really see what you are going to eat!The same goes for al the pastries and cakes ! And i would highly recommend their Bread and butter pudding ( which is made out of brioche.... stop thinking about the calories, its desert ) and their bailey's brick( and this is my only complaint.... has become smaller)  Its a great place that even on the dreariest days in cheerful and lively!The perfect place to meet up for coffee or lunch, and I hear dinner though I am yet to convince someone to go with me !

5ZV9NWPe6vLe0GanvZ4KkA.text: I walked all the way to this place just to take a picture from the food selection they have. But when I asked for permission they said no! Snif! So the picture is from the outside, and I just have to describe how delicious looking all the food really is!All the Italian treats are displayed on big bowls when you walk in. Yam! The most difficult part is to choose what you want to have. During the lunch time the place just gets so busy that is hard to get a table, but they do take a way a bit cheaper prices so that is a good option as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

NQaWsG0gZ02mx2zmCPrA-g.text: I've heard so many good things about the food at Ottlenghi, and have ogled the cakes through the window before now. Unfortunately, I haven't had particularly good encounters with the staff here. The first time, I tried to go for tea and cakes with some friends, but the woman at the door was very snooty and dismissive, like we had to grovel or something. There were plenty of free seats, but she said something about it being the changeover from lunch and said she could squeeze us in if we waited about 20 minutes. We really didn't like her attitude so took our business to Carluccio's instead and had some very nice cakes there. The next time I went, we did get in but they sat us right at the end of a large table (where we felt quite exposed  there was nobody else sitting on it, and there were tables for two available elsewhere). They then started to move all the furniture around in a flurry of activity (they change it for evening service apparently). It was very disruptive and they completely forgot to bring us our order! I had to go and tap someone on the shoulder to remind them in the end. They were very huffy and not very apologetic. Honestly! I find the staff here very superior indeed (in a bad way), I don't know where they find them. Perhaps they are out-of-work actors, they certainly act like drama queens. I hope the food is worth all the kerfuffle, the cake certainly wasn't. And it was very expensive too. I won't hurry back.

BgUCBWxoQG33Doxt2no9SA.text: Mr (or possibly Mrs, or even Ms sorry Otto, I have no idea) Lenghi writes a food column in the Saturday Guardian mag in which he, or possibly she, lauds the virtues of fresh veg, herbs, and putting them together in clever ways. So far, so granola-eating Guardian-reading yawn, you might say, but the proof of the salad is in the mastication and in this case he, she, it or they have got it exactly right. As far as I can tell, this little chain of eateries takes its influences and style from the Med southern Europe and northern Africa, with lots of little spices and tangs to transform humble dishes into bold flavoursome experiences. I've only been to the Upper Street one but I'm sure the other outlets pull off this clever feat with similarly accomplished aplomb. I won't even try to list dishes because they usually come with about 14 different ingredients which somehow pull together to create something very special. It's fantastic for brunch or lunch, not wallet-shrinkingly expensive, and usually pretty friendly and welcoming. A perfect place to take your loved one for a Saturday brunch-type canoodle. Top notch.

zGrHTpSb81eTWuxSA089Iw.text: Was visiting from out of town and if everywhere in London served food as good as this, London would be known as a world class culinary city.  Had a good mix of veggie and meat plates, one thing better than the next.  Make sure you put the croquettes on your must-order list.  We put in 2 orders after the initial one because we couldn't get enough.   Don't skip desert, but check out the selection beforehand in the window, just to make sure there are no regrets on what you order.

1CgpfQfQbrtTNT8X3aR0RQ.text: I've actually never ate at Ottolenghi because it is generally always packed.  But, I regularly pick up salads, quiche or dessert and each experience is better than the last.  They have an amazing focus on sourcing and using the freshest ingredients in all of their dishes.  If you can't stomach the prices, I recommend their cookbook -- pages and pages of food porn.

xJlb9cgZWSDNKk_y0HNulg.text: I can't say enough good things about Ottolenghi without getting all gushy. My wife and I had just come in from Germany (Oktoberfest) where we had way too much brown food with lots of beer; so we were ready for something green, fresh, and, of course, tasty. A friend told us to have lunch over at the Ottolenghi. So, we made out way towards Ottolenghi. The place was packed with takeout orders, but the nice lady at front sat us at a table in the back, which was perfect. Anyway, we ordered three salads each and, to make a long story short, the food was fantastic. A little pricey and snobby, but well worth it.

eBFYvBS-bwWzTXmKksTZPA.text: Yep, giving it a 5!  I just love so much about this place--I just love that everything is white to accentuate the colors of vegetables and fruits.  I love the way they display salads and desserts like art.  I love that there is a world of flavors explored--from Latin-inspired spicy mango over beer-battered monkfish, Asian-inspired tuna with panko and wasabi cream, to sweet cabbage with lovely venison.  The passion fruit tart and the chocolate rum fondant are fantastic and it is the best latte in the neighborhood.  Service with a smile?  Yay.  Big thumbs up.

vRA72JGYnuDzIzHXKecFtg.text: Great food, so tasty and well presented.  We resisted the deserts but may go back for them as they looked amazing.  I would have given 5 stars but the staff were a bit annoying...

eFQziRrkytq-oaHlfCsO6w.text: I have to say that the salads here are the best I've had in London.  All thee shared dishes are well-prepared.  I love seeing all the food in the window

JG3z8yQs3cTSRhVJKDOZjA.text: I only had tea and cake here so can't comment on the rest of the food but the rum and chocolate torte was divine. Don't know how much it was as I din't pay but I'm guessing it was pricey. Seats unfortunately were a bit uncomfy so if I'm on my own dime I may head for carluccio's instead!

w1PFuFp7M58t_mZMQ9MmCA.text: One of my favorite places in London...top ten. Every time I go i think it is even better than the last time. You select from the various dishes they displayed in the front. Usually  a half dozen veggies and a few meats. Standard faves include aubergines, steak, and brocolli. And the desserts can't be missed no matter how full you are. They have extraordinary breakfast as well. I little pricey but a must-go.

dR8dkleZ8ZdxArH4FnlZ-Q.text: You can't help but notice the neatly stacked pink meringues and tasty delights in Ottolenghi's windows as you walk past. Whether you're up early for breakfast, craving a mocha or searching for a salad, you can find it here. Its modern, bubbly atmosphere means you can chat with a friend or sit solo with a great book. The long communal table at the back is great for groups or meeting a stranger over a desert.

Swg2iHEAJMDRswYkHS_rRA.text: We came here to get some dessert to-go and we ate it outside from the box in a matter of minutes it was so ridiculously good.  We got the chocolate and orange cake and the vanilla and apple cake.  We scarfed it down like disgusting American tourists and we didn't even care about being judged because it was just that amazing.  I have worked as a baker and tend to be picky about cake, but I had no complaints at all.  I think the man working at the counter was rude and didn't seem to want to tell us what various desserts were.  I think it might serve them well to make signs, thought that might take away from the visuals, it sure would help.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

Jnr3bs1av9EZs-WLx-8cZA.text: What: brunch.When: a nondescript Wednesday morning.With: my two best female friends.It's lovely to go luxe for brunch when it's cold and miserable outside. My friends and I met here, a short walk from Highbury & Islington station (Victoria line), to celebrate an engagement. The blonde had the eggs and smoked salmon, the brunette had the cinnamon french toast, and I had the bread board (yes, we love our carbohydrates). We also asked our waitress if they could make us some mimosas (they weren't listed on the menu) to celebrate the blonde's engagement -- they could, they did, and they were yummy.Be prepared to sit at communal tables (à la Pain Quotidien) and under the connecting cables of the toast-it-yourself bread toasters at each end. Be prepared for the waitresses to offer you three different menus (two of our waitresses were confused whether we were there for breakfast or lunch, and another waitress figured we would benefit from more choice). Be prepared for the unisex bathrooms...Aside from those preparations, the flagship restaurant of Yotam Ottolenghi seems a very pleasant space. Mr O graced us with his presence (surely very unusual for most namesake restaurateurs?) and the whole restaurant was abuzz with contented eaters. Everything smelled delicious. Alas, I was too full from our carbo-centric brunch to eat it all -- but I got a pain au chocolat to take home, which -- now that it is tea time -- tastes DIVINE.It's a little pricier than your average café, but then again it's not an average café: it's Ottolenghi's flagship restaurant, and a darn good place for brunch. Looking forward to eat dinner here very soon...[p.s. You don't need to sit down to eat. They do lots of yummy take-away things. We pressed our noses against the window for a while before we left. Oh, Mr O :) ]

paw9EVWQcDYgv7idsdx1QQ.text: Oh, Ottolenghi. Why is it that so many restaurants in London contain the same letters? Otto, Ottolenghi, Cotto. The Ottolenghi empire specializes in drool-inducing window displays and the food does not disappoint.This is one Ottolenghi where you can sit down and eat with table service. Beware, though. It's incredibly popular, so come early (11:30) or be prepared to wait. One thoughtful staffer was handing out pieces of breadsticks to hungry patrons in line.If you're like me, and you love vegetables, meat, and dessert, this place is for you. For lunch/brunch, you'll get your choice of 2-4 delicious vegetable salads with or without a piece of meat or fish. You will be stuffed.I had the salmon, plus three vegetable dishes: aubergine with tomato, butternut squash with sour cream and paprika, and sesame green beans.I'd recommend this place for vegetarians and vegans.Gluten-free notes: Most of the food here is naturally gluten-free. And when you look in the window to see plates piled high with gorgeous baked goods, smile. A good number are gluten-free! I've tried the poleta cake, fondant chocolat, and chocolate tea cake. All are delicious, moist, and wonderful. They don't bill them as "gluten-free" with any sort of sign, so just ask. Your gluten-eating friends would know that they are delicious and not guess that they happen not to contain wheat.

-ZQ0VjelMDUJ-Zl9MynE2A.text: Eff yes. All the time.Worth the wait. Worth the trek. Worth the calories. Worth the price.If you're a fool like me and fancy yourself capable of reproducing some of his incredible creations if *only* you just had his cookbook, allow me to dispel any illusions of grandeur. You can't.Magic.

p7LLTMaNl8hToE8JS_ThdA.text: What a great place on Upper Street, which I suspect will easily become one of my favourite spots in Islington. There is a a casual yet up-market vibe to this place.Truly fantastic small dishes to share (a combination of salads, cold pre-prepared appetizers, and small hot mains. Food was to-notch. Definitley try the sea bass and the prawns....so flavourful and well prepared. I think I dreamt about the later that evening. My friend raved about his spicy aubergine appetizer.Desserts looked amazing (check out all the meringues in the window). I had a passion fruit meringue tarte that was simply delightful and paired with an equally nice dessert wine.Ottolenghi was packed for dinner (well it was Saturday night), but they made room for us on this massive long common table. Definitely worth a stop...even if only to look at the fancy desserts in the window.

4eHYwwIeulHYZ9djW9JD6g.text: There was a profile on Ottolenghi in the New Yorker, which piqued my interest and I'm so glad it did.  The beet salad was amazing as was the Asian inspire pork dish.  I was already having a wonderful meal and then dessert. . .. salted caramel chocolate tart, it was divine.  I thought the meal itself was reasonably priced,  I enjoyed the atmosphere here slightly better than that at Nopi.  I can't wait to go back.

EJrlbBT3XXGq_NsbR9_stA.text: We just ate there tonight. Everything was fabulous. Each dish was unusual with amazing favors including pomegranate, basil, cumin seed, tarragon, hazelnuts, pistachios.  We could eat there every night. The wine list was fun and not overpriced. And the service was attentive and friendly. Highly recommend the zucchini flowers tempura, the English beef filet with coriander sauce, the eggplant with yogurt sauce and the green beans.

Prdp7kLtRZTvD-mmDKtoYg.text: I have given 5 star reviews on Yelp before. But absolutely never have I meant it as much as I mean it now.  I had a truly enlightening experience at Ottolenghi. I have the "Plenty More" cookbook at home, so I had high expectations for the meal.  I am a vegetarian and I went with two carnivores. We ended up getting 3 veggie plates and 4 meat, and all ended up stuffed. I personally enjoyed the brocolini, pea and mint fritters, and the carrot puree. Each dish glorified the vegetable at it's center and made me reassess my understanding of flavor combinations. It's the kind of cooking that inspires you to be better to your food in the kitchen, and that gave me a certain high from the real goodness of the meal. It shouldn't be a surprise that anyone I tell about this restaurant is trapped for at least 15 minutes while I go into a reverie about my experience. It's not an inexpensive night out, but it's worth every penny for the genius of the cooking done here!!!!!

WazCwKK4JKkx--zOTuG8Iw.text: I'm not even a really big fan of coffee, but I had the best latte of my life here the other week.  creamy, with notes of caramel and butter. it was mind blowing. and who can go inside and not leave £15 lighter with a box or two of DELICIOUS.fresh green salads and veg, marvellous pastry, cakes(the financier is my most favourite! you can't not love beurre noisette), and other tasty nibbles.I seriously think I just gained a stone merely thinking about Ottolenghi.

q-abJWFH2UtguA-oaWRtWQ.text: Got a takeaway box of the salads, which were good. Though still had to wait in a 15 min line. I was disappointed with the black currant meringues; they were a lovely color and texture, but had a strange savory, almost fishlike taste that I was not expecting.

pP-ZSPaywiVTTkeri30f8w.text: I am a big fan of Ottolenghi and the inventive approach to cooking that they promote. I love walking in past the days' arrangement of salads and cakes, it's a great way to get your appetite going. The displays seem like they should belong to an old French patisserie but for some reason they fit in beautifully with these ultra modern and sleek surroundings. In fact, the only thing I dislike about Ottolenghi is that everyone else loves it so much too. Queue's here can be an absolute nightmare and because there is such a limited seating space they don't tend to move very quickly either. The staff are very aware of this though and very attentive to the queue. I've even known them to walk up and down distributing nibbles which really does make the time pass a bit faster. The popularity of Ottolenghi is also reflected in its prices and a bowl of soup will set you back Â£6. Don't be too put off by this though as the quality of cooking is really high and while it might be a bit too expensive to visit every day, it's perfect for a special occasion. If you're ever in for breakfast try the mushrooms with feta as a side dish, a little extravagant but absolutely lovely!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

N4TkimdwsRPAVqKPDrBaRQ.text: Went to try and get salads for takeaway. We stood there for a while with no one offering to take our order. There was no organized queue so the staff just rushed around and helped people who had entered after us. We were standing right in front and no one even acknowledged us at all. Was very excited to try the food but was turned off by the horrible service. We ended up leaving empty handed.

7ZvxzyX4PYRfSXIMgFV18Q.text: The line was so long we only grabbed desserts. But, the counter staff was incredibly nice - we grabbed a few sweets for the day- the berry cheesecake and the peanut butter s'mores were dreamy dreamy dreamy!! Will have to come back for a meal soon...

RCJaUeZ9VNfPt6TAm9D-Jg.text: Summary: Good food, pricey, cool interior.Tried this place for breakfast twice. Once as a sit down meal for the brioche french toast w/ berry compote and greek yogurt, and a second time for takeaway almond croissant.The french toast was good, but not phenomenal. This may be stylistic preference, but the bread wasn't custardy and soaked through. The bread seemed like it was dipped in egg wash for a few seconds and then cooked, so the center was still dry. The compote was good, but even better were the various spreads (butter, banana compote, thick hazelnut chocolate spread w/ whole hazelnuts, and berry jam) on the table. Banana compote + hazelnut chocolate spread on french toast is a pretty solid combo.Almond croissant was good, but not the best I've had. The outside wasn't consistently flaky. Some pieces were, some weren't. The center had a massive amount of marzipan - I think I prefer a thinner layer in the middle.Separately, I've also gone to the Kensington location a few times and tried the savory pesto muffin (great) and various cakes (good).Food overall was good, but given the price premium (and reputation, although I suppose it's a bit unfair to judge based on reputation), I expected consistently great if not phenomenal food.Interior was pretty cool - clean, crisp white interior. Beautiful layout of the baked goods. Had seating. See the photos for details.Would come by again, but probably wouldn't go out of my way. Food was good overall, but pricey for what it was.

nUnaZeKa0A818wrt6oDAGw.text: desserts....the best desserts ever!salads...the best salads ever!meat....the best meat ever!Heavenly heaven.Never disappointed, always getting excited about going back. Service is great too!

uaqPSXARcS8EGoF-SBHOUQ.text: Fabulous, fabulous, fabulous! Wow. I have only been here for takeaway breakfast and brunch but it was delicious. The presentation is incredible and they food is nothing but delicious. Their vegetable portions are very generous at a reasonable price. If I lived in the area, this would be my go-to every morning or evening I didn't want to cook!

1W97hT4kqUfBzwkuHESy8Q.text: Ottolenghi is the best!!!  Come for the cookies, stay for the salads.  A Saturday trip to Ottolenghi totally makes my day and I make sure to stock up on cookies and other goodies for the rest of the week. There are others in Belgravia and Notting Hill, so no excuses not to stop by!

R24FIotmirrGfU4mmKFYGQ.text: Ottolenghi is one of my favourite Sunday brunch locations.  The restaurant is in the perfect location, it's close to shops and a nice easy walk into Angel.  The white walls and furniture can be a bit stark, but the wood floors balance out the space.  To be honest, your eyes are almost instantly drawn to the various food displays, so dancing bears could walk by and I'd doubt you'd notice.  The food in the window seems to go on and on, surprising, I have never ordered the food on display.I know you can order the food that's on display while you are eating in, but I always order from the menu.  I must admit, I'm a creature of habit and 99.9% of the time I order the Eggs Florentine.  I love the combination of spinach, poached egg and hollandaise.  There is something about the hollandaise at Ottolenghi that is just right!  I have no idea what's in it, but I know what it's supposed to taste like and all I can say is Umm Umm good!  It's not just the hollandaise!  The egg is perfectly poached with just a bit of yoke and the spinach is just right.  The mixture of flavours are delightful and before I know it, my eggs Florentine are gone!  To wash my brunch down the fresh orange juice or hot chocolate help end the meal perfectly.Ottolenghi also serves lunch or dinner, thus far I've only been for Sunday brunch, and as for brunch, this place is spot on!

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

FOO6VPMbeFZbX8SNIMOxgw.text: Ottolenghi is probably the archetypal Upper Street cafe. The food displays are sumptuous and incredibly inviting. The cafe is quite small with a large food display area at the front and tables at the back. There is one large, communal central table that occupies much of the seating area. I came a few weeks ago for a late lunch with a friend. It is a sort of buffet where you choose your food from a combination of dishes. The food is healthy Italian with a good range of salads. We had a glass of the house/cheapest white with our food which was surprisingly good: delicate, poly tonal and all that. As one might expect from this sort of place, the people can sometimes be unbearably bourgeois, which can mean conversations about whether to send Ralph private or public, which is fine but can be a bit of a chore if you're sitting on the communal table. A pleasant place that does simple, good quality Italian food well, though if you're going try to avoid yuppie rush.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

3PYw-6y7UbCvF7CGNIsPVg.text: Upper Street famously has some statistic along the lines of the most restaurants per yuppie in London so in theory it should be incredibly easy to get a great meal there. Sadly, many of the restaurants are sad pseudo-trendy relics serving decidedly mediocre food. However this cannot be said of Ottolenghi, a relatively recent gem of a restaurant. Your mouth starts watering as you walk up to the window, where tasty treats are piled high in a mouth-watering display, including gigantic meringues, mad enough to be straight from the pages of Alice in Wonderland. The decor is cool, mimimalist white, seating at one long white table down the centre of the room, providing the perfect no-fuss backdrop to the delicious food. Fresh and inventive salads are the savoury speciality - although it's not strictly a vegetarian restaurant, anyone with vegetarian friends to cook for should come here for inspiration in how to cook real, interesting food for non meat-eaters. Although the savoury food is worth the journey alone, it's worth saving space for pudding as the cakes are deliciously home-made tasting (if you lived with Nigella Lawson, Delia Smith and Nigel Slater or something) and gorgeously displayed. The brownies are my personal favourite and if you can't manage anything straight away, you can always take away to eat later at home.

photos.caption: Photo of Ottolenghi - London, United Kingdom

g5N3I21BquOeTGLdzMxjBA.text: On our second night in London for a conference, I talked my co-worker into dragging our jet-lagged bodies from the King's Cross Holiday Inn to Upper Street to indulge in a dinner at Ottolenghi. She seemed unconvinced as we walked toward Upper St., and was obviously scoping out other potential dining options along the way. But I persevered, and she was audibly impressed by the magical myriad of sweets in the window when we finally reached our destination. The attentive staff quickly accommodated us in spite of our lack of reservation and my long list of food allergies. We perched at the bar and enjoyed two very interesting reds recommended by our cordial server from their impressive list. We started with the green and yellow bean salad, the beet and pistachio salad, then she had the duck egg in miso and I had the peanut-crusted tofu. Everything we ordered was fresh, perfectly prepared and seasoned, beautifully presented, and utterly delicious. For dessert, we had a pretty amusing exchange with another member of the staff (floor manager, perhaps?) who was excited to discuss the amount of alcohol in some of the baked goods. My co-worker's eyes lit up as he recommended an individual cake--I think he said it had Bailey's, some rum, and even perhaps a dash of Guinness in it--served with crème fraîche.  "I believe you've taken me for a boozer, sir," my co-worker said, "and I think I'd like to go with your recommendation." While my co-worker attempted to make her way through the 80-proof cake, I enjoyed a fresh mint tisane and the fig salad for dessert. She managed to finish about half of the cake, but not because it wasn't delicious. We'd already sampled a good cross-section of the menu, and she physically couldn't eat any more (plus I think she might have worried that I'd need to fireman-carry her back to the hotel). She probably would have taken the leftovers with her if we'd had a mini-fridge in the room.Ottolenghi was definitely the best dining experience we had during our recent stay in London, and I highly recommend it--especially if you're recovering from jet lag and need some pampering, or if you have a hankering for amazing food and boozy cake.

aCHsAsUXtvf8Pme0HkDVwA.text: My favourite restaurant in London, particularly the restaurant on Upper Street. Everything is wonderful from the aperitifs to the desert wines.  I always make a point of going here when I am in London!

1O421Ystis8nf-lZFegcpA.text: Ottolenghi feels like the restaurant's equivalent of a shopping mall. There are people everywhere, the general staff is indifferent, and you choose several items which appear almost instantly, after which you are quickly ushered out on a conveyer belt so the next customers can have the same experience. Crowded seating leads to severe social claustrophobia and makes one want to eat as quickly as possible so as to escape watching other customers do the same. The food is creative, fine, but that's just one component to fine dining, and this is not a fine dining experience for anyone who does not have a Charles Darwin-length beard and a copy of Finnegan's Wake on hand.

Nq8hpW_h-7arH413QYjw9Q.text: An amazing place without a doubt. If you are not drawn in by the beautiful window display of delicious desserts than you will be by the menu. The menu lists sides and then mains- of which you pick and choose your selection instead of ordering a meal where the sides would not have been your first choice. Dining is on large tables where you mix with other people (which was great as I met some great people to my left) as well as smaller private ones. The food is spectacular, the service was brilliant, the meal superb, and the desserts.... oh the desserts! I highly recommend.

jBe0pZX-OEAr_vQsG7-H1Q.text: The food and combinations are inspirational and taste divine. The cakes, oh the cake display is immense and makes choosing all the more difficult. But there is no such thing as a bad choice as they are all diet breaking worthy. Go. You must.

x6aEOm5fLB623LveDAo6Nw.text: Beautiful and understated decor.  The restaurant was very busy and coming to the end of the afternoon sitting but they made us feel welcome and like we had all the time in the world.  I had the beef with horseradish and some seriously incredible salads. I have Coeliac disease and the server was able to tell me immediately if I should avoid a particular dish - no hassle. It is usually a bit of a faff when I eat because I need to avoid gluten but it was a wonderful experience. The wine was delicious. We were too full for dessert but we did manage to buy some cakes on the way out for later. No problem with a gluten free cake and they provided a candle for my husband's birthday bun which was really sweet. ~Go for the food and the atmosphere.

XpK1shEc6cNDMpC21EHArA.text: Love this place! Amazing flavours and choices. Can be tricky to get a table though.

E88UFaqYqSuGepkQSHGN2Q.text: Having drooled over their lunchtime window displays, heard the winning reports, and tested my way through the Ottolenghi cookbook, I was excited to finally have the opportunity to try the restaurant.Securing a late reso, days in advance, and mid-week, we arrived to an 'every table full' and buzzing restaurant. We were quickly seated and presented with menus and the ordering began. As it's sharing (and between four of us), we tried most every dish on the menu. Some were better than others, but nothing stood out enough that we wanted to order it again. In fact, overall, we were pretty disappointed. The food was good but not amazing. The service was apathetic at best and brazenly up-selling at worst, and at the end of it we were left still feeling a little bit hungry.For the price and the ambiance (elbow-to-elbow communal long-tables), portion sizes are too small: 4small slices of beef fillet or 2 lamb popsicles isn't a great deal for £11; esp if the flavour and presentation don't blow you away.I'd not rush to go back and if I did, it's probably going to be at lunchtime for the great salad selection. Guess I'll have to continue working my way through the cookbook.

cyFvGW50-Wge0eUxgORBkw.text: Went there with a firend who is already a great fan, and I was not disappointed.Service was EXCELLENT! Food delicious: you got olives on the tables when you arrive to nibble on until your dish comes. We both had pizza, which even if a safe option, tasted delicious.

I968HzZInYniT2Idnn82pw.text: The restaurant is modestand clean, with some unique art like painting on the walls and a semi-openkitchen where you can see the staffs working there. The cornmeal crust pizzas are perhapsthe finest tasting gluten-free crust I've ever tasted. The slices are plentywith toppings and cheese so it is very satisfying.They also have vegetarian selectionsand spicy pepperoni. I wastotally impressed with the quickness of service they have. For the gluten free vegetarianslikeus, this place might be the perfect place to visit.

YezAZCGslo8nOJuaJIClJA.text: Ohhh!!! Ottolenghi. Oh to have met earlier in the day. Oh my gracious, Oh a Plenty. Having had a sad time at an eatery nearby, I knew all would be well again having coffee and dessert here. No booking required as many suggest, a risk at almost closing time, but staff were wonderfully welcoming, despite no doubt having a stonkingly busy day and dealing with Oohs and Aaahhs and indecisive patrons ogling the plethora of treats. Nigella, my heroine, you and your Lemon Polenta cake can go fly a kite. After momentarily scanning an abundant array of delights, what caught my eye in what I think is akin to the Selfridges Christmas window display of carbs against a clean landscape of white, was one last solitary seductive treasure on a winning pedestal. There were lots of other delicious looking things, but this, be still my excited taste buddies. Crowning this glory, wearing a glossy dark coat of chocolate ganache, underneath I could tell it was moist even from a distance; Ottolenghi's polenta cake was an orange almond offering with a few chicly positioned toasted slivers of almond teetering on the edge, as was I. There was a small queue, I was beginning to bite my lip in anticipation that someone may take this last beauty before I managed to order. The waitress efficiently showed us to our seats, " Just to let you know we're closing in 20 minu-", (never have I been so quick to order with a menu in my hands) "I know what I'd like and I'll be so eternally pleased if it can be mine, it's the last-"Almond, Orange, Polenta, I'll go take it for you now". She finished off my sentence and was back in a flash with an equally delicious fruity and rich black coffee and, oh a piece of the most glorious dense unctuous orangey, orange blossoming in my roof of my mouth and sticking to my hips, smooth buttery, of course not too sweet but nutty and sophisticatedly chocolatey...oh do excuse me....

oPY6v6MFhqLEMlFFFrvueQ.text: I have been a big fan of Ottolenghi's food writing now for quite some time. A Saturday is complete once I have read his latest offering in The Guardian. I also own two of is books and often like to look at them, peeking almost as if I don't want to get caught, lusting after photographs of aubergine, dressed in yogurt sprinkled with pomegranate seeds glistening up from the pages like jewels. This man is the Hugh Hefner of food porn. Everything you want to have and one portion isn't enough. Ottolenghi is a playboy mansion for foodies. His tarts are too obvious to go for. When I went there last week with my beloved we wanted everything. It was a polyamorous feast of the senses. A mezze platter of taste sensation only it was small plate eating. Now I have to break this discourse in what would be somewhat of a food porn fairy tale to mention that small plates still equals big prices. But you know something, once in a while it is nice to feel delightfully ripped off. The food we had was INCREDIBLE like really really incredible. I got off looking at the bread alone which OH MY GOODNESS it was good. His skills as a baker shone. The texture of the foccacia left me wanting more. The olive oil for the bread selection was also wonderful. Peppery yet smooth which allowed the sensual pleasure of the varying textures of the bread to be fully devoured as it seduced the mouth. The 'No Carbs After 6pm' curfew was well worth lifting to eat this bread. OK if you were a coeliac this is the part where you will be yawning away. I don't blame you. For our meal we shared some chargrilled courgette, with pecorino and truffle oil. Everything was offset and balanced against each other in harmony. We also had some Artichoke, Raddichio and faro which was served with lemon and broad beans. Again he triumphed with that one! We then had some scallops that were served on a thick pulse broth, and to top it were some tempura anchovies and some deep fried onion. This was a dish that shone out for me and the scallops were seared so they were meltingly sweet and almost caramel in places. We also had some mackerel that was served with a beetroot and apple salad. This too was nice but I was more into the scallops than anything else. We had a glass of white wine to go with it....unfortunately I forgot the name but it was Italian and £6 a glass and was the only wine priced at that so go figure! To end with My beloved had a chocolate tart thing and I had a tart that was white chocolate, lemon and raspberry. Mine was lighter and the zingy tang of the lemon made the dessert clean tasting on the palate and was rather refreshing. The chocolate tart had a little rum in and was nice but was rather dense. Definitely a dessert for girls who love chocolate. Whilst my beloved licked her lips and transported herself to a chocolate nirvana. I was having a dirty foodie romp with my tart which took me to nearly the realms of a dodgy fantasy. We were both in food utopic voyages that our tastebuds allowed us to have a collective yet individual dining experience. The food was just as beautiful as is presented in the books. It reminded me of The River cafe in many ways. The simple food, bold flavours, simple presentation. But the freshness of the produce, the vibrancy on the plate and the effect on the tastebuds was astronimical. I see the fuss and excitement about Ottolenghi restaurants and yes it was a little bit pricey I definitely want to go back, especially to experience what it is like at breakfast as well as lunch. Next time I need to take a cake somewhere this shall also be one of my main ports of call. It simply has to be done once in a while.
